TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the deaths on 27 November 1988 of Mr Edmund Maxwell Cameron Fox, CBE, a former member of the House of Representatives for the division of Henty from 1955 to 1974, and on 25 November 1988 of former Senator John Albert Little, from Victoria.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF FORMER SENATOR JOHN ALBERT LITTLE

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on 25 November 1988 of John Albert Little, a Senator for the State of Victoria from 1968 to 1974, places on record its appreciation of his meritorious public service and tenders its sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I support the motion of condolence which has been moved by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray). On behalf of the Opposition I express my sympathy to former Senator Little's family-his wife and two sons-who have survived him. We acknowledge the work which was done by the late Senator Little who, as a key figure in the Democratic Labor Party, played a part in what was regarded as an important element of Australia's political history. We express our sympathy to his family at their loss of a husband and a father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself with the motion moved by the Government and seconded by the Opposition. I just make mention of the fact that, as I look around here today, I do not think any persons present were in the Senate when Jack Little was here. He was here until 1974.
—Senators Durack and Gietzelt.

—Senators Durack and Gietzelt are not currently in the chamber. Apart from Senators Durack and Gietzelt, I do not think there are any current senators who were here at that time. Jack Little was one of those senators who held the balance of power, and it is interesting to reflect that it is only a relatively short time since then. Jack Little was a colourful speaker; it has been said that he was able to speak under water. The difference between Jack Little and many others was that he made sense on any subject on which he spoke. He was quite an orator. He came through the trade union movement the hard way and, on many occasions, had to speak against all odds.

SPEECH.PARA: Jack Little was once President of the Victorian Branch of the Australian Labor Party. Throughout his lifetime he served the workers. In fact, he was only 41 at the time of the traumatic events in the Victorian Branch of the Labor Party in 1954-55. Those must have been difficult times for Jack Little. It must have been a difficult political choice for him to have made at that time because he had a young wife and a young family. We need to recall the sacrifices that persons such as Jack Little made. In 1952 he was elected as a member of the Legislative Council for Melbourne North and remained so until 1958 when he lost his seat. He was a very active unionist in the Boot Trade Employees Federation.

I note that his funeral service is to be held today at 11 o'clock. He had been ill for at least two years and I would like to join the Government and the Opposition in expressing my sympathy to his wife, Ila, and their two married sons and their families.

PETITION.TITLE: In-vitro Fertilisation Patients: Medicare Funding
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament
The petition of the undersigned shows a request for Medicare benefits for in vitro fertilisation for the medical treatment of infertile couples.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled grant Medicare benefits for in vitro fertilisation, IVF, for the medical treatment of infertile couples 1 in 10 Australian couples are infertile and unable to conceive and carry a baby to birth. Having a family is one of the most fundamental and rewarding aspects of life and benefits the community as a whole. IVF is an established and proven treatment for infertility. There are existing mechanisms to regulate and control IVF, including the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee. Currently IVF patients pay up to $1500 per treatment cycle for IVF out of their own pockets. This means that some couples who need IVF to help them establish their own family do not have access. We request that Medicare funding be granted for IVF for the treatment of infertility and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

1. That it be recognised the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill is a public, legal acknowledgment that Australians who are non-aboriginal do not have sovereignty in their own country.

2. That the Australian people are opposed to the idea of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Australian people who are non-aboriginal and those who are aboriginal, and the Government has no mandate or authority to pursue it.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced:
A Bill for an Act relating to the importation into Australia of, and the classification, in a Territory, of, certain video material, and for purposes connected therewith.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of the Bill is twofold. It is:
1. to prohibit the importation, sale or hire of ``X'' rated videos;
2. to reduce the violence in ``R'' rated videos.

As Deputy Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, I have waited patiently for the Government to respond to the majority report of that Committee brought down in April 1988. The accepted timetable for the Government's response to Committee reports is three months Mr President, it is now seven months since the tabling and the Government has only in the last couple of weeks reported to the Senate. The response was a complete farce. It has hidden behind a supposed need for a further committee of their Caucus to be set up to make sure there is no supposed confusion about what ``X'' rated videos are and to review the level of violence in videos. What the Government has really done is to acknowledge it intends to support the multi-million dollar, hard-core porn industry, despite the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee and against the expressed wishes of all the Attorneys-General of the States.

On 30 June this year following the tabling of our report all the Australian Attorneys-General met and as a result of that meeting an unanimous agreement was reached between the States and Commonwealth Attorneys-General. It was agreed that most Australians wanted ``X'' rated and excessively violent videos outlawed and that the way to accomplish this was that there should be a national approach on the issue. This was necessary, Mr President, because while all the States have for some time banned the sale or hire of ``X'' rated videos under their jurisdiction, the Commonwealth had refused to do so in the Territories, resulting in the free trade of these videos being carried out between the States and Territories and so thwarting the States legislation. Mr President, the Government had so strongly supported these ``X'' rated videos that over a period of four years it has delayed time and time again any action being taken to support the States in this area.

Many Government members claim adults should be able to see and read whatever they choose, believing that there should not be any censorship. However, they happily go along with the need for censorship of child pornography, bestiality etc . . . It is really only a matter of where the censorship line is drawn not whether there should be censorship.

During the Committee hearings, evidence was given by many social and behavioural science researchers that they believed prolonged viewing of ``X'' rated videos could have very detrimental effects on certain individuals with aggressive tendencies but perhaps the evidence I appreciated most was given by Professor Sheehan of the Queensland University when he said:
. . . the critical thing in whether or not there will be these so-called effects of sexually explicit material is how aggressive the person is in the first place . . .

There is no question that a lot of people are stimulated mildly or strongly by seeing sexually explicit material. When one is aroused one tends to behave as a consequence of that arousal and I think if the person is aggressive aggression will out . . . In and of itself, I do not think that sexually explicit material divorced from aggression leads to strong negative effects. Once you combine sexually explicit material with aggression you have a different kettle of fish . . . The critical thing is how much someone is aroused and how aggressive he is in the first place (Joint Select Committee Report p. 207)

When you consider that evidence in conjunction with the other evidence we received, Mr President, and you look at it in light of the latest Australian survey on domestic violence which shows that 22 per cent-or one in five-of Australian men are so aggressive that they believe it is acceptable for a man to use physical force against his female partner then we have a potentially explosive situation. Females of all ages feel threatened and are becoming increasingly concerned for their personal safety. Women's groups throughout Australia have expressed their concern, they have a right to be protected. It is ironical, Mr President, that ``X'' rated videos are considered too degrading to be shown in cinemas but are considered by this Government suitable for home entertainment.

The second part of the Bill is to reduce the degree of violence in ``R'' rated videos. As a Committee we had great difficulties in finding suitable words that would permit the showing of the every day ``cops and robbers'' videos but exclude those depicting extreme violence. Presently the Film Censorship Board's guidelines exclude videos that depict ``detailed gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty.'' I have added the word relished so that it now reads ``detailed, relished or gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty.'' This will remove all depictions of acts showing people enjoying committing violence and I believe will certainly remove the worst type of violence that is of such concern to the community.

Mr President, my Bill has a clause that will permit, with the Attorney-General's approval, an organisation to import video material to be screened at a special event. An example of this would be a film festival. It also allows the Film Censorship Board to classify material which it considers of such educational, cultural, scientific, historical or cinematographic significance that it is in the public interest for it to be classified.

Mr President, I believe it is vital that this Bill be supported. Action must be taken to stop the increase in the incidence of violence in this country. In the past 10 years the incidence of serious assault has increased 228 per cent, while the incidences of rape has increased by nearly 140 per cent. We cannot ignore these figures or make excuses by attempting to find fault with them.
As legislators, it is our responsibility to do everything in our power to make Australia a safer and happier place in which to bring up our families.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The action is typical of the way the Government is handling health services in Australia today. It seems to me that it has allocated 7.5 per cent of its tax revenues to health services and is now cutting the services willy-nilly here and there in order to keep them below its 7.5 per cent allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: The determination was brought into the Senate two days after it came into effect. We were debating it here, realising the disastrous effects it would have on our pathology services in Australia, after it had already come into effect. The Health Minister would not listen to any reason at all. The pathology services in Australia were going to have to alter all their computer programs, at enormous cost, only to have, we hope, the determination disallowed. However, he went ahead willy-nilly. A court case ensued. The debate was delayed and now the matter has come on for determination by the Senate.

I might say that during the formation of this determination there was very little consultation with the pathology services. In Australia we have developed probably the best service in the world. The pathologists had had, admittedly, years of plenty, but they had developed services which applied to both city and country, whereby one could get same day service for one's pathology results, and these services took the load off the Government's services and those supplied by the State governments. Admittedly, there had been examples of overservicing, but this was as predicted and expected, and surely could have been corrected without the blunderbuss approach that the Government has taken.

The Opposition agrees with the Government's thrust to contain costs and reduce abuses. The two main pathology groups in Australia, the Royal College of Pathologists and the Australian Association of Pathology Practices, agreed fundamentally with the Government's aims. They were assured that this measure of cutting out half the services that attract Medicare rebates would be revenue neutral and was designed only to prevent abuses. The pathology groups accepted the Government's means of attacking the problem. They were mollified by reassuring statements from the Minister. But on detailed examination of the proposal-a working model was designed-they found that their patients would be profoundly disadvantaged. These findings, by the way, were verified by two private accounting firms and by the Department of Community Services and Health. But the Government has attacked with a heavy hand, as it did recently with the pharmaceutical benefits restrictions which largely had to be reversed. We debated that problem in the Senate last month. In effect it was a similar kind of determination to this one the Government again used a blunderbuss approach. The Government, thinking only of cost containment measures, has struck virtually half the pathology services available from the Medicare schedule. This will have an immediate effect in that the income of private services will drop by 15 to 20 per cent and the State services by approximately 30 per cent. The kind of services available from private and public services will be reduced because their income will be cut so severely.

Rural areas, of course, will be particularly affected. The collection of specimens will be affected. The same day service will have to be abandoned. Many people will be put out of work. On a conservative estimate, in Queensland alone, about 2,500 people will lose their jobs. This will further overload public services which are already overloaded. They will not be able to cope because their income will be cut even more severely than will the income of private services.

This determination will have a major detrimental effect on health care in Australia. It may even be a health hazard to Australia. Delays can mean the difference between controlling a disease in its early stages and even the loss of a patient's life. The pathologists have remonstrated with the Government, but their complaints have fallen on deaf ears. Departmental officers have admitted their mistakes. They argue that the new pathology services' table should come into effect the day before the initial debate on the matter in the Senate as planned, after which the pathologists could make representations to the Government on an item by item basis.

The Government has made a huge mistake with this pathology schedule determination. The financial effects are far more serious than it intended or than the pathologists were led to expect. By not responding to the pathologists' appeals the Government is maintaining its belligerent stance towards doctors and pharmacists generally, and now pathologists. Some pathology practices could go broke under the new schedule.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope not.

—Some will. But it is the patients who will be the ultimate losers. For a Government that promised the fairest, freest and most equitable health service in the world, it is now restricting the service so that it, in itself, is becoming a health hazard. The new schedule represents a direct threat to the practice of first class medicine in Australia. The core of the problem is, of course, Medicare itself, a service which promises free health care at the point of delivery, a promise which is impossible to fulfil. In fact, as the demand for services goes up and the budget for them goes down, the two are disappearing away from each other and creating discontent in just about every field of medicine in Australia today.

SPEECH.PARA: So the Government is reducing the services in order to contain the costs to its predetermined Budget specification. It is really a cruel and inhuman way to attack the problem. The Minister undoubtedly has his socialist goal of nationalising pathological services in Australia and driving private laboratories out of business. If he persists with this kind of determination, it is likely that that will happen. The same-day service will be a thing of the past and the extra costs needed to make laboratories viable will have to be passed on to the private patients. Rural patients will, of course, be the first to suffer. There have been massive representations on this issued because it affects such a widespread number of people throughout Australia. It has happened despite warnings to the Government that it will have these detrimental effects. The Government has pressed on regardless and this has caused no end of disruption to the services.

I understood that originally the Australian Democrats were disposed to act in a humanitarian and Hippocratic way with regard to this determination and to support the Opposition in rejecting it. However, I understand that as usual they have changed their minds and they are now going to support the Government simply on representations made to them--

TALK.START.PARA: —You can hire them by the hour these days.
—I have heard that, Senator. They used to be hired for longer periods, but it is on an hourly basis now.
—The politics of envy, that is all.

—The politics of envy, greed, hatred and cruelty. While walking along a hallway this morning I noticed an advertisement which said that the Democrats want to stop us having any fun, and it then mentioned the things the Democrats are against. But this is not fun. We are dealing here with people's health and lives.
—They think doctors have too much money, so they penalise the patients as well.

—I really believe that is the issue on which the Democrats have made their determination. As far as I know they were informed by the chairman of the committee that inquired into this that these pathologists were earning $400,000 a year, so they believed they were ripping off the system, they were greedy doctors-all the usual charges that are laid against doctors. But they did not take into account the costs of running a practice and how much it costs to provide all these services. Just looking at the gross overall figure, the Democrats have decided that the pathologists are earning too much so they will cut them down to size. That is not the situation at all. Certainly by providing services on a wide scale pathologists do have big incomes compared to other people, but there is an enormous cost involved in getting those incomes. They willingly pay that over the years and this has led to a Rolls-Royce pathology service in Australia. The Democrats want to cut it to a Mini Minor type service and that will be to the detriment of us all.
—At least they're consistent; they sold out the pharmacists as well.

—They are consistent; they did sell out to the pharmacists, and then the Government had to change its mind in that case and had to reinstate a lot of the items that had been struck off the pharmaceutical benefits list. To my mind the Democrats are just political tumbleweeds. They blow with every wind and hope that it is favourable for them. They are not really concerned with the issues at hand.

SPEECH.PARA: The action of the Government in this case is entirely consistent with its belligerent stance on health services in Australia. That does not just extend to the doctors, the pharmacists, the pathologists and the radiologists but also to the nursing homes and hostels. This morning we had representations from the Victorian nursing homes and hostels about the way in which they are being cut down in the same broadsword, across-the-board fashion. That is just not good enough. The Opposition will oppose it, and I express my disappointment with the Democrats' whole attitude to these problems. They have taken their minds off what is good for Australia; they think they are doing what is good for the Democrats but it is not even good for them, as is shown by the fact that the Government had to reverse the decision that it took on the pharmaceutical benefits.

The Opposition is moving to disallow this regulation which is, I think, the only sane and humane thing to do. To expect the pathologists to accept this kind of treatment and then go back to the Government and negotiate on an item by item basis is unprofessional and uneconomic. The effect on the patients concerns me most. I wholeheartedly reject the attitude of the Minister for Community Services and Health to this determination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak only briefly to this disallowance motion. I would like to begin by addressing the process because Senator Sheil and some of his colleagues including, much to my surprise, Senator Puplick on the front bench, seem a bit bemused by it. Relatively frequently the Australian Democrats, in the first instance, support the Opposition in moving for the disallowance of regulations. That is a process which has taken place before and quite possibly will take place again on the basis that that gives time for everybody to address the specific regulations, the issues underlying them and the concerns of the community. Indeed, that has been done before. I have been party to that process in some of my portfolio areas, just as Senator Coulter was in this portfolio area. Unlike the Opposition or the Government, the Democrats do not come at issues necessarily from a narrow minded, blinkered and ideological position. It seems to disturb the Opposition that we use the time gained to consult, confer, consider and make decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: In the instance of pharmaceuticals, which was referred to by Senator Sheil, I make the point that while he seems to be condemning the Government for some kind of backdown when it actually made some substantive changes, he should consider that representations by the Democrats in expressing concern and our ability to act in this place from time to time may have had some bearing on that process. In this particular instance, as with others, we supported the motion to enable the disallowance to come before the Senate and, as I recall, we also supported extension of the time for the motion on a couple of occasions. Through that process of time and deliberation we have now arrived at the decision that now that the vote is before the Senate-that time having been given to the Senate-we will not support the disallowance itself.

As I said, that has happened before and will no doubt happen again. We do not believe that the intervening time is a waste of time for anybody. For example, the extra time allowed the concerns of people involved in in vitro fertilisation (IVF) programs to be raised. As a result the Government has included a temporary item until the end of March of next year so that those concerns can be further addressed. I suggest that that is one concrete instance of this process, in which we have been engaged, being effective on one of the specific concerns in the area.

Senator Sheil referred to the politics of greed and envy; he was ascribing those politics to the Democrats. But those are among the words that the Democrats would use in explaining one of the reasons for our decision not to support this disallowance. In none of the literature from pathologists complaining about the fall in income that they would have under the new fee structure has any indication been given of the pathologists' absolute incomes. I would like to give some of that information here now. The Senate should realise that the figures I am quoting are net figures, after allowing 87 per cent for costs. The average income of pathologists in private practice is $224,500 a year. The median income is $203,000. A few private pathologists actually receive over $400,000 per annum and the lowest income is $87,000 per annum. I repeat that these figures are net figures after allowing 87 per cent for costs. And we are accused of the politics of greed and envy.

Senator Sheil used the term `unprofessional' in complaining that, subsequent to the passage of these regulations, pathologists and others concerned will have to make approaches on individual issues and items. He said that that was unprofessional. I find unprofessional the fact that a letter is being given by private pathologists to patients blaming the Democrats for the increases which will occur subsequent to the passage of this determination. I consider that to be highly unprofessional. Of course, we had been informed of that prior to the vote on this motion today. I think it indicates a willingness to get involved in an unacceptable approach which could be labelled an attempt at blackmail. So if we are talking about unprofessional behaviour, I certainly think that is a problem to which attention should be drawn.

There are still some anomalies in the system; there always will be in this kind of process. As I have said, one of the problems has been allowed for in the IVF area and that is something which we are pleased about. There are some anomalies and it is within the purview of the Government, and certainly of the Minister, to address those anomalies. I have no doubt that, after the opportunity that has been provided by the time that was given via our original support of the motion moved by the Opposition, those concerns have been brought to the attention of the Government, and I have no doubt at all that they will continue to be. We have no objection to that and we will support these expressions of genuine concern. Further, I have no doubt that the Government will address those concerns where they can be shown to be genuine in terms of the real issues and not some emotional appeal to us, as decision makers in this place, about a loss of income for a most privileged group of people in the community. So the Democrats will not be supporting this disallowance motion. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for the absence of the Minister who has been handling this matter. I will make just a couple of points about the matters raised by Senator Sheil today. The first thing Senator Sheil did was to hop into the Australian Democrats because they have changed their minds. I do not think that is particularly fair. I am not a particularly fair person, but I would have thought that it was an honoured process in this chamber for one political party to have a spear at the Government, for the Government to react and adduce other facts, and for the parties to reconsider. It certainly keeps the Government on its toes when it hears that, in a particular instance, the Democrats will not support us but that they will support a disallowance motion. That certainly forces this Government to advance strong and clear arguments. That is part of the parliamentary process. Senator Sheil has been here long enough not to get upset by it. Really, I have very little else to contribute to this debate. I will defer to my honoured colleague from Western Australia who has graciously deigned to appear in the Senate to discuss these matters with us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that we are debating the motion for disallowance. Such a cue to my intervention in the chamber could mean nothing else. I thank my colleague the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) for such an introduction.
—You have the numbers. If you haven't got anything to say, don't try to say it.

—I have quite a lot to say, because I think the Government's position should be clearly and unequivocally placed before the Senate, given that the disallowance motion has arisen here in the form that it has. Obviously, I oppose the disallowance motion and, in doing so, I will start my presentation with a series of quotations. The first is from the Hansard of 11 September 1985. As an aside, 11 September 1985 was the tenth anniversary of an event that I hope will never recur in this chamber. But that is another matter--
—I thought that happened in November.
—That happened in November 1975.
—So what was the event in September?

—It is two months short of the 10 year anniversary. Having made that point, let me leave it aside, because it is a disgrace to this chamber that that event occurred at all. I quote from the Hansard of 11 September:

SPEECH.PARA: However, pathologists operate in an environment where for the unethical the possibility exists to make extra money. It is up to the Parliament-it is up to the Government-to ensure that those loopholes are closed.

Philosophically, the Liberal Party of Australia endorses and encourages entrepreneurial endeavour, but in the sense that it is applied in this report, that activity, I must emphasise, is indeed repugnant.

The quote goes on in a similar vein. On that occasion the speaker turned also to the document that was being debated-the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on Medifraud-and quoted approvingly these words:

It was only when the automated machines came on the market that a very few clever, let us not denigrate their intelligence, a few extremely clever medical entrepreneurs saw their opportunity. They had a vision of buying some expensive machine, putting a person in front of it, making a million dollars-and they did. The little people will be squeezed out because they do not have that mentality.
My third quote is from another speaker in the same debate, this time on 11 November 1985. That speaker said:

I wish to devote my time today to talking about what probably constitutes one of the gravest threats to the revenue of the Commonwealth which has arisen in recent years. I refer to the growth of what has become popularly termed as entrepreneurial medicine. I propose to say something about the current situation as far as pathology is concerned, particularly in the State of New South Wales, and to say something about some of the persons, companies and organisations which are currently engaged in a major rort of the public health system in Australia.

The speaker then turned to the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled `Medifraud and Overservicing-Pathology'. He went on to quote a series of excerpts which are too long to retail in this speech, but I will pick up the quote where he said:
At paragraph 4.9 the Committee says:

The Committee believes that many of the entrepreneurial medical schemes currently in operation violate at least two conditions outlined by Dr Thompson, i.e. they abuse the national health scheme and involve unethical behaviour.
My fourth and final quote in this series is from the speaker I have just quoted. He said:

The advertisement was headed `Pathology . . . a disgusting state of affairs in New South Wales!' Three eminent, respected pathologists, Doctors Michael Barratt, Dermer Smith and Michael Harrison, inserted the advertisement which, in part, read as follows:

Unfortunately in NSW there are a significant number of medical practitioners who, as O.P. Approved Pathology Practitioners, refer their patients' pathology to pathology laboratories knowing full well that the standard of pathology performed by those laboratories is low and that by so acting they are placing their patients in danger. They are acting in their own financial interest by virtue of the fee split and are putting their patients at serious risk. These laboratories, by churning out reports which cannot be trusted, are a great threat to the patients of NSW.

I could give further quotes. I have by no means exhausted the range of possible quotes to illustrate the point I am making. I have quoted just two speakers. The first two quotes I cited were from Senator Watson, a Liberal senator from Tasmania, speaking about the Public Accounts Committee report in 1985. The second two quotes I cited were from Senator Puplick, who has today moved this motion of disallowance, in the same debate, in his case on 11 November 1985. He was speaking in the appropriations debate and referring to the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on medifraud. Those quotes illustrate one of the prime reasons why this Government has moved to a course which has now come to the Senate and which I hope the Senate today will conclude to enable the pathology services of Australia to be sorted out in a way consistent with good public administration, ethical and professional medical behaviour, and a concern for the economics of medical delivery.

Before I go to some of the details of why the Government has supported the report that is now the subject of this disallowance motion I wish to refer to some other documents. The Sydney Morning Herald recently, in the Good Weekend magazine-the lift-out magazine of that newspaper-ran a series of articles concerning entrepreneurial medicine. The body of those articles makes it clear to any reader that entrepreneurial medicine is a symptom of the malady which is endemic in the pathology services in Australia. I do not want to quote all of the most impressive statements, but I think for the record some should be put down. I will pick up on the second page of the article. In referring to pathology it says:
There are clinics dealing with anything from menopause to sports injuries. Billboards advertise: ``This week, $3 cholesterol test. Save $5 or maybe a lot more''.

In return, patients do not even have to reach for cash. The costs are paid indirectly and almost solely by the government through Medicare. The Bill for Medicare last financial year Australia-wide was around $3 billion which represented 135 million services.

It goes on to talk about entrepreneurial medicine. On page 30 of this feature article, a major headline in the middle of the page says, `Centre doctors are offered possible future ``higher rewards for repeat patient numbers'' '. On page 33 under the heading, `Are you being overserviced?', the article states:

We used to call it McDonald's medicine-in and out with a smile and a blood test-we've always got a smile. It's part of the McDonald's service. (A doctor commenting on her job at an entrepreneurial clinic.)

On page 35 of this feature there is a picture of Dr Andrew Gibson of Pacific Medical Centres. The article reports him as saying that he has been offered tens of thousands of dollars by pathology companies.
On page 36, the concluding page of this article, it says under the feature headline:
``I've had pressure to do more x-rays.''

It quotes a doctor as saying that. No-one, not even honourable senators opposite or, indeed, the mover of this disallowance motion, on the record denies that there is a problem with excessive overcharging, excessive abuse and excessive problems with the Medicare system with respect to pathology. These anecdotal features in the Sydney Morning Herald are not something that I would normally rely on in making a point. However, they illustrate graphically in journalese the dimensions of the problem. It is common ground between independent and objective observers of the Australian medical system that there are problems in pathology which have to be sorted out. It is an area of abuse.

What forms does the abuse come in? Let me give the Senate one example of a form of abuse which is of considerable concern to the Government. Doctors claim under an incorrect Medicare item under the schedule which will pay a higher rate for a simple test, and sometimes a claim is two or three times more rewarding financially for them if they improperly list a particular test under the old schedule. The new schedule that is sought to be disallowed by the Opposition will clean up that practice. I have another example of abuse under the old system: doctors will order a test and many more tests than are necessary to be performed will be performed, and each particular test will be charged. That is one of the reasons why fees are blowing out in the way in which they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did that come from?

—That is an example of abuse that is known commonly and is detected from time to time. It is one of the things that the adoption by the Senate of the report we are discussing will help to wipe out. I would have thought that in the face of that type of thing we would not today be meeting full on a motion moved by Senator Puplick which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the determination of the pathology services table, contained in Determination PST2/1988 and made under section 4a of the Health Insurance Act 1973, be disallowed.

If that motion were to be carried, the sorts of practices which Senator Puplick himself has complained of, which Senator Watson has been vociferous about, which the Sydney Morning Herald illustrates, and which the anecdotal evidence I have given demonstrates, will be unable to continue. It is a responsibility for this chamber to defeat the disallowance motion and prevent that from occurring.

In view of what I have said, let me go back a little in time to the areas that were referred to by the report that Senator Puplick and Senator Watson were speaking to in 1985. In many respects that report is a tribute to the system of government in Australia which enables bipartisan scrutiny of issues of this nature. That Public Accounts Committee report led to a series of steps by this Government which culminated in the setting up of PSAC, which is a medical acronym for the Pathology Services Advisory Committee. I need to emphasise and underline the point that this body was set up with and on the advice and with the agreement of the Opposition and the medical profession. The body is composed of representatives of the medical profession, from the Australian Medical Association (AMA) and pathologists, to look at what can be done in this area.

There have been the routine, regular criticisms that attend the declaration of any matter which addresses a problem. There have been criticisms of PSAC that it has not consulted widely enough. The record shows those criticisms to be hollow: it has exhaustively consulted. I emphasise again that this body was set up with the approval and support of the Opposition and with the support of the medical profession, the group of people over whom it was to exercise judgment. It was chaired and is now chaired by a Deputy President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, someone used to dealing with issues of salary, reward, payment and meeting of obligations of individuals in the work force and in all walks of life at all levels of the work force. The Deputy President, Mr Justice Paul Munro, has served on the bench of the Arbitration Commission with distinction. The Committee proceeded to analyse, inspect, investigate and take submissions, and it has reported.

We are bound as a government under the terms imposed on us by the Opposition and by the profession-something that we agreed to at the time, it is true, but because of the urgings and lobbyings of the profession and the Opposition-to accept that report or to reject it, not to discriminate as to whether we accept it in part and reject it in part. We have the choice of throwing the whole thing out or accepting the whole thing. Faced with that choice and with the problems in pathology, the only honourable and proper thing to do is to accept the report and to defeat this disallowance motion. It is not as if the Australian taxpayer has no problems in meeting the cost of medical services in Australia. It is a proper exercise of prudent and responsible government to make sure that the best medical services are delivered at the most efficient cost.

Total Medicare benefits paid in this country in 1987-88 amounted to $2,881,786,339-not an insubstantial amount. Pathology accounted as a component of that for $426,102,006. That is 14.79 per cent of the total amount paid out in 1987-88 in medical benefits in this country went to the payment of pathology services. Also, it is not as if pathology services are not a growing component of the total payout of Medicare benefits. It has not remained constant. Medicare benefits for general practitioner services have grown by around 5 per cent per annum but the growth in pathology services has been 10 per cent per annum. So not only is a major component of what is paid to the medical fraternity for delivering services to patients being now diverted to pathology, the increase in the amount diverted is greater.

I want to underline significantly this point: it is important always to recognise that often where these sorts of abuses occur the vast majority of the people in the profession are not at fault. It is at the margins that unscrupulous practitioners ruin the game for everyone else. I think that is true here because PSAC is composed of people who give voice to the pathology profession and intrude into the considerations of PSAC the sensitivities necessary to see that pathology is properly and economically delivered in Australia in an orderly way. Therefore there does not need to be criticism of the body of the profession; it is those that abuse the system who should be criticised. That is an important point to remember. The majority of the profession, a majority of pathologists, I believe support what the Government is doing in sorting out the table that we have before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a scatter-gun approach.
—Madam Acting Deputy--
—President.

—I thank Senator Puplick for his assistance. I often do not need it but I am searching through my papers. An interjection is made that there was a scatter-gun approach. Honourable senators opposite may look in startled shock at that allegation. It came from their colleague, Senator Sheil. Honourable senators opposite may cleave to that interjection and not modify it but in some respects it denigrates pathologists themselves because, as I have said, pathologists have worked in PSAC along with other medical practitioners and experts to come down with this report. If it be a scatter-gun approach-an interjection I reject-that is not an attack on the Government but on the people in that Committee who brought down the report and on their expertise and professional standing.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to go through a number of points briefly which I know will prove conclusively that the PSAC deliberations have been proper and orderly. First, the Pathology Services Advisory Committee, as I have constantly tried to underline, is not an unsubstantial body: it was designed to give the profession a voice in the maintenance of the pathology services table. It is a hands-off body for the Government: we accept or reject. The Committee is chaired, as I have said, by a Deputy President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and there are two nominees of the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia, Doctors Carter and White; one nominee of the AMA, Dr Niselle; and there are three ministerial nominees-Professor Bell, a pathologist from the Prince of Wales Hospital; Ms Seyfang, a senior medical scientist from the Victorian Cytological Service; and Mr Read, an officer of the Department. That is the body that the interjection sought to cast a slur on. The College and AMA nominees in particular have a vast amount of experience in dealing with pathology issues relating to the various medical benefit arrangements. Dr White, for example, was involved as far back as 1970 when the first medical benefits schedule came into existence. Dr Carter is a vice-president of the Royal College of Pathologists and Dr Niselle is a former member of the Pathology Benefits Subcommittee. The ministerial nominees were also appointed on the basis of their potential contribution to the workings of PSAC. Professor Bell heads a large public hospital pathology laboratory and Ms Seyfang represents the interests of medical scientists who carry out the vast majority of pathology tests. Mr Read was nominated for his background in health policy and for his economic expertise. That is the body of which the criticisms are made. I think it is a body which any government would be pleased to empanel to advise it on a complicated field such as this.

In December 1987 PSAC took control and direction of a working party which had been developing a revised pathology services table. The membership of the working party included the two College representatives on PSAC I have referred to and some of the other people I have referred to as well. The processes of the working party involve examination of the various documentary material on interpretation and revision of the table. Information on the incidence of claims against items on the existing table was made available by the Health Insurance Commission working party, which was also able to draw upon sources experienced in the administration of private pathology practice for the purposes of identifying the pattern of demand for pathology services.

At its March 1988 meeting the Committee noted a draft table prepared by the PSAC working party and proposed to consider it as an interim revision of the current pathology table. The Committee required that the draft be circulated on a confidential basis to various groups. The draft provided to the AMA included schedule fee levels proposed at that time. Fees were admitted from copies provided to the other professional organisations. Detailed comments were received from some groups, submissions and comments were considered by the working party and on more detailed matters there was, in some instances, informal discussion on points raised with representatives of the body making the submission or the comment. Submissions and comments were also available to members of the Committee, which considered and made amendments to the draft table, having regard to the comments and submissions received.

Representatives of the Australian Association of Pathology Practices (AAPP) met with the chairperson and the secretary of PSAC who put the views of the Association to the rest of the Committee. Suggestions and comments from the AAPP were at varying levels incorporated into the discussions on new pathology tables and were reflected in the recommendations. A recommendation on the new pathology services table was sent to the Minister on 31 July. The need to undertake this work and completely revise the pathology table had become critical for a range of reasons which had developed over the past decade. I have gone through a number of those reasons.

I conclude by making these points: there is a problem. That problem has been bipartisanly recognised in this chamber. That problem has been a matter of popular comment in the press. That problem has been addressed by a joint committee of the Houses of this Parliament. That problem has been identified. That problem has been acted on by the Government. The Government composed a committee representing the professions and people skilled in making decisions on remuneration. That committee then took on a life in which it exercised its powers of investigation and forensic research, consultation and its obligations to then test against its client group its preliminary findings and modify and reassess those findings. That body sits on the basis of regulations-regulations agreed to by the Government but put to us strongly by the Opposition and the profession-that we accept or reject. Given the dimensions of this problem, the degree of consultation and the conclusions of the report, there is no choice but for this chamber to vote against the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful that the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, in his introductory remarks was kind enough to quote at length from a speech I made in the Senate on 11 November 1985 in which I took a leading role in drawing to the attention of the Senate the need to clean up rorts and improper practices within elements of the medical profession and, in particular, within certain sections of the pathology services area. It is perhaps interesting that on the front of today's Sydney Morning Herald we see the news that Dr Edelsten, the practitioner on whose practice my speech focused, has been struck off the register by the New South Wales Tribunal. I am grateful to Senator Cook for having drawn attention to this matter because it makes crystal clear the permanent campaign which the Opposition has waged to ensure that steps are taken to clean up the rorts and the economic-almost criminal-malpractices within the Medicare system. That establishes quite clearly our bona fides in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: We would not be here arguing for disallowance if we believed that the primary issue was one of financial malpractice. We are arguing for disallowance because we believe that the primary issue is proper health care for the people of Australia. It is interesting that, whereas on 2 November when the debate on this matter started, the Government's argument was `Here we are, trying to do something about the health care system', now the Minister comes in and says `What we are trying to do is to eliminate the practices of these thousands of fraudulent pathologists who are ruining the system'. The Government's argument, no longer being sustainable on its public health merits, has to be turned on the question of whether there are people out there rorting the system. The Government, no longer being able to sustain the argument on its public health merits, retreats-as it so often does-into an abuse of the profession and of the good people involved in the profession.

For the Minister to come in here today and make comments about why the Pathology Services Advisory Committee (PSAC) has to be regarded in a particular fashion, saying that its recommendations have to be in holy writ, when presumably the argument he has been putting in Caucus for the last couple of days about the Remuneration Tribunal's recommendations on parliamentary salaries is that it is important that the Government overturn the judgment given by the independent tribunal set up for this purpose, is perhaps a matter of some considerable interest to people who are looking for a degree of consistency from the Minister in this regard.

I want to focus on three matters: first, the extent to which PSAC has got the sums wrong and the fact that the determination should be disallowed because its calculations are fundamentally wrong. Secondly, I want to address the question raised as to whether this is a debate about the income of private pathologists or whether a far more important issue is at stake; namely, the capacity of the pathology services operating within the public health system to cope with this new table. Finally, I will come to the arguments put up by both the Australian Democrats and the Minister about the processes and about PSAC and its procedures in this matter.

It will be recalled that in the early stages of this debate everybody was told that there would be an impact on the incomes of pathologists and on pathology services of some 2 to 3 per cent. That was going to be the reduction in income. That was the basis upon which PSAC was making its calculations. We know from page 13 of the original report from PSAC, dated 31 July 1988, that when the Committee was asked to deal with the question of economic modelling in this matter it was unable to establish a proper and effective model which could be applied. However, the model the Committee did use led it to the following conclusion. I quote from the report:

When a similar exercise, that is to say essentially a modelling exercise, was attempted within some private practices variable results were obtained due to differing tests combinations. An overall reduction of 5 to 8 per cent was found but the statistical sampling was not large or widespread enough to give a clear indication in respect to the true financial impact.

That 5 to 8 per cent made the rounds as the argument in terms of its potential impact upon pathology services. If, however, one looks at a minute D. J. Elias, Senior Adviser in the Health Benefits Division of the Department of Community Services and Health, addressed to Dr Deeble on 11 October 1988, one will find in Elias's minute to Dr Deeble, after having gone through the question of the examination of a number of practices, this comment:
Overall these data suggest the likely impact on practice income is a decrease in the range 15 to 20 per cent.

In other words, within the Department of Community Services and Health, between the PSAC comments of 31 July and the minute of 11 October there has been a revision, with 5 to 8 per cent now suddenly becoming 15 to 20 per cent. That is only in regard to private practices surveyed and says nothing about the impact in those practices within the public sector, where in fact that decrease will be getting up towards 30 per cent.

When one looks, for example, at the minutes of the PSAC meeting which took place on 17 October 1988, one sees recorded the following references to comments by Mr Read, who was so comprehensively praised by the Minister just a couple of moments ago. At paragraph 3.8 of the minutes we read:
Mr Read indicated that if the evidence of a possible reduction in the order of 15-20% was before the Committee when the original decision was made, then he would have made a different decision.
At paragraph 3.11 we read:
Mr Read feels the Committee is now in a position of defending a table on which it did not have a lot of information initially.

In other words, we have in the minutes of the PSAC meeting of 18 October recorded comments saying that, had PSAC had the information that it how has available to it at the time when it was making its original determination in this matter, it would or probably would have made a different determination. One finds, in looking through the documentation which has now become available, that PSAC itself is under no illusions about the fact that it got its sums wrong and that if it had had the information available to it back in July it would not have made the determination which we are now seeking to disallow.

Nothing could more clearly indicate the attitude of this Government than for it to be coming into the chamber with the support of the Australian Democrats and saying, 'We believe that PSAC is the appropriate body; PSAC has admitted that it made a mistake; nevertheless, that mistake must be sustained'. That is what the Senate is being told today.

The evidence is there, and admitted by the advisory body whose determination we are now determined to uphold, that it made a mistake; nevertheless, the mistake must be sustained. That is the way in which this Government runs the public health services of this country. The Government was told on 21 October, in an article in the Australian Financial Review by Julie Power headed 'Cuts in Medicare pathology schedule to save $100m':

A "revenue neutral" decision to halve the number of items on Medicare's pathology schedule has threatened the financial viability of public and private practices and unwittingly saved the Federal Government $100m.

That, of course, is what it is all about. It is all about the determination that a sum of money is to be saved and that the public health cost, the cost to individuals in our community, is to be set at nought against that particular determination.

I look, for example, at the annual report of the Health Insurance Commission for 1978-88 which was tabled today. When I look at the tables at the back, dealing with the numbers and percentages of services provided through the Health Insurance Commission system, I note that pathology services are shown in this period to account for 21.7 per cent of the services processed by a broad type of service and for something like 15.19 per cent of the benefits actually paid. I do not believe that there has been any evidence that that in fact represents an incorrect, excessive or improper balance of medical services to be designated in terms of the pathology sector. If, however, it is this sort of calculation upon which the Government is now basing the determination of public health issues, let me say that the radiologists and, indeed, the providers of optometrical services ought to be considerably worried about their future, when one looks at the figures which are in these tables, as to who is going to be next on the Government's hit list. This is no way to run a public health service. Yet that is precisely the sort of argument that the Minister for Resources who represents the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) comes in and puts before the chamber.

I turn now to the question of whether this is all a matter of rich pathologists rorting the system, which seems to be the sole argument that Senator Powell was able to put forward today. I raised in the debate on 2 October the particular problem of the Taylor Square Private Clinic run by Dr Basil Donovan, who is one of the leading people in Sydney involved in the treatment of the AIDS crisis. This matter was raised on 20 October 1988 in the hearings of Senate Estimates Committee F, where Senator Peter Baume was asking Dr Deeble some questions and demonstrating through those questions the impact upon that small private clinic of this new series of pathology determinations.

Dr Donovan is not, I presume, part of the rip-off merchant syndrome that appears to have got so much under the skin of Senator Coulter and Minister Cook in the course of this debate. Dr Donovan is not such, so much so that one knows that the Government will have to make some special arrangements with him to allow his practice to continue to provide the services that it does, because his practice cannot continue to provide those services if this pathology determination stands as it is. Certain other arrangements will have to be made, without which the treatment of people who are HIV positive, or who are otherwise under Dr Donovan's care as part of the program that he runs at the Taylor Square Private Clinic, will be severely prejudiced.

Let me come to some of the other representations that have been received. I have here a representation from Dr Munro, of the Department of Anatomical Pathology at St Vincent's Hospital in Sydney. His letter has on its letterhead under the logo, might I say, these words:
Under the care of the Sisters of Charity.

Dr Munro says that as far as St Vincent's Hospital is concerned the sustaining of this determination will have a major impact upon the way in which St Vincent's Hospital is able to carry out its work. He says in part:

The schedule does nothing to correct the ever-widening practice of ``skimming the cream'' of pathology. By this I mean systematic concentration on low cost tests to the exclusion of difficult and/or unprofitable procedures.

In other words, St Vincent's Hospital says that it does nothing about the major problem which ought to be addressed but it does impact on a hospital such as Dr Munro's. I have a letter from Dr James Wiley, the Director of Haematology at the Austin Hospital in Heidelberg, Victoria. He says:
The new Pathology Table will have its major impact on public hospital laboratories because of the marked decrease in Medicare benefits for the more sophisticated tests . . .
I have representations that come from the Haematology Society of Australia. It says:
The new Pathology Services Table would seem to be detrimental to good patient care in a number of ways.
I have representations from the Department of Medicine at Westmead Hospital, which says in effect that this determination will bring about the following:
The overall consequences of these changes must be disturbing to anyone with a social conscience-
from which one excludes the Australian Democrats-
(a) There will be two levels of medicine-one, ``bad'' practice, for the poor, another, ``proper'' practice, for the well off.
(b) The genuinely sick in the community will have to pay.
(c) Good pathology practice will either have to lower their standards of service or become bankrupt.
I have a letter in similar terms from the Royal Melbourne Hospital, which says that the proposed schedule:
Introduces a financial disincentive to the detailed investigation of complex patients who are privately insured.

I have representations from the Department of Cytology at Westmead Hospital in the same sorts of terms. I have a representation from Dr Lowenthal, Reader in Medicine with the Department of Medicine at the University of Tasmania, which says:

The new regulations which came into operation on 1 November 1988, will have a disastrous impact on small, specialist laboratories. These laboratories, which are sited almost exclusively in universities and teaching hospitals, often in conjunction with research facilities, are non-profit making and perform a vital role: they are the resource for the performance of difficult tests, for example for tissue typing for transplantation, for analysis of lymphocyte subsets for patients with leukaemia and AIDS or for hormone analysis.
I have a letter from the Vice President of the National Venereology Council of Australia. It says in part:

The facts are that there is effectively a 60% drop in the rebate for standard sexually transmitted disease testing (eg. culture for gonorrhoea, antigen detection test for chlamydia, syphilis serology, hepatitis B serology.) The direct outcome of this cut in the rebate is that private pathology laboratories will be either reluctant to perform the tests (it will hardly be worth their while), and will direct practitioners to divert their tests to a public laboratory-(these are already overloaded with work from the public STD clinics), OR will refuse to bulk bill patients and will instead (to maintain their incomes) continue to charge the old fees (for which patients will only receive a very small part back on medicare).

These are not rich grasping pathologists. These are not pathologists in private practice who, because they are allegedly making large sums of money, have whipped up the Democrats into their self-righteous fury of indignation on the basis that somebody is being paid large sums of money. Given the choice, the Democrats will say to the public sector, the University of Tasmania Department of Medicine, the Westmead Hospital, the Haematology Society, the Sisters of Charity at St Vincent's Hospital and the Austin Hospital, `Let them all go hang. What the devil do we care about these people in the public sector?'

There are out there one or two rich pathologists creaming off the system, and the Democrats, the professional practitioners of the politics of envy, in typical Democrats fashion come in here and say, `Given the choice between the health of Australians and the viability of the public pathology practices and the incomes of a few rich doctors, we would rather have people potentially die and we will eliminate their capacity to have proper health treatment in this country because there might be one or two rich doctors making a bit of money out there'. Given the choice between getting stuck into a few allegedly rich doctors and protecting the public health facilities of this country, the right to public health treatment of ordinary citizens and the rights of hospitals like St Vincent's, the Austin and Royal Melbourne and the little laboratories at the departments of medicine at universities around the place, the professional politics of envy practised by the Australian Democrats is to be given preference.

Senator Powell came in here and rabbited on about who makes $80,000, when her Party has certainly not been to the forefront in knocking back increases in politicians' salaries. She rabbited on about the fact that some pathologists might make a few extra dollars if this determination is not disallowed, and says to St Vincent's, Austin Hospital, Sisters of Charity, the Medical School at the University of Tasmania, the people in the Haematology Society, the people of the Taylor Square clinic and the people of the Venereology Council of Australia: `Bad luck. You can all go hang, because we are so concerned that there are one or two people out there making money'. For Heaven's sake, because there are one or two people out there making money they would close down the whole system on the basis of figures from the Pathology Services Advisory Committee, which figures were admitted in its own minutes in October to be inaccurate. That is precisely the way in which the Australian Democrats behave.

On 2 November Senator Coulter said, `We will support this disallowance motion'. What happened? The judge who chairs PSAC and the members of PSAC were sent around to lean on him. They took him to see the Minister who leaned on him, saying, `Look here, Senator Coulter, people are making money. There are actually people out there making money from this whole thing'. Of course, Senator Coulter's jealousy hormones got all stirred up about the fact that somebody out there is actually making money, one thing he does not want anybody in this country to be able to do. Then, all of a sudden, because he has been given some shonky figures about the incomes of private pathology practices, he is off and away and has decided that once again here is a good opportunity to get stuck into people like that-and to hell with the public health consequences of the determination that he will make. Given the choice of putting the slipper into a couple of rich doctors or protecting the public health status of the people of Australia, he has no doubt whatsoever how he will come down at the end of the day.

Even when the figures are explained to the Democrats carefully and they are asked to do something as simple as to make a distinction between net and gross incomes, that in fact is a little too difficult for them. It is too difficult for tiny parties and tiny minds to sort out the fact that there are differences between these figures and the global figures with which Mr Justice Munro, PSAC, the Minister for Community Services and Health and everybody else have snowed the Australian Democrats. In order actually to sort out the difference between net and gross incomes and the differences between fee levels, gross revenue, payments to pathologists and an excess of pre-tax income over costs-under those circumstances-do honourable senators know what one has to do? One has to put prejudices to one side and look at facts. The capacity of the Australian Democrats to put prejudice to one side and look at facts does not exist. Indeed, if one looked at facts one could not be an Australian Democrat. It is by definition impossible both to have regard to facts and to have membership of the Australian Democrats.

Under those circumstances we get to the situation that we have got to today. The Minister, having talked about how important and relevant PSAC is and how everybody is happy with this independent authority, of course did not indicate that the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia, one of the important constituent bodies of PSAC, at a meeting on 17 November, resolved unanimously through its Executive:

Having reviewed the procedures and operations of the Pathology Services Advisory Committee . . . both generally and with particular reference to Determination PST 2/1988, the Executive concluded that the present structure and procedures do not permit the views of the College and its members to be properly represented and taken into account, and unanimously determined on behalf of the College to request you the Minister to terminate the appointment of the members of PSAC nominated by the College, pursuant to Section 78H (3).

In other words, we are now brought back to a review of the principles which the Minister has put before us for the determination of this matter. First, he said that PSAC recommendations ought to be prima facie accepted because it is a body acceptable to everybody who is involved in the process. That was shown to be nonsense when the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia indicated that it wanted to withdraw its nominee from PSAC because PSAC simply did not work effectively in taking account of its views. Secondly, he says, `PSAC has all the facts. You bring the facts together, you examine those facts, you accept what they say'. The minutes of the last meeting of PSAC indicate, in the comments of Mr Read and others, that they got the facts on the prior determination wrong. Had they had available to them then the facts which they have available to them now-and I refer again to that quotation:
. . . if the evidence of a possible reduction in the order of 15-20% was before the Committee when the original decision was made, then he-
Mr Read-
would have made a different decision.

That 15 to 20 per cent figure is not my calculation. It is not a figure which I have plucked out of the air. It is the figure which appears in the minute from Mr Elias on 11 October to Dr Deeble-a minute within the Department of Community Services and Health headed, `Impact of New Pathology Services Table'. The Minister, having argued for the integrity of PSAC, finds that shot out of the water. Having argued for the validity of the figures which PSAC has put before the Government as its determination, he finds those shot out of the water.

At no stage did the Minister, Senator Coulter or Senator Powell attempt to address the question of the impact of this determination, not on private practitioners but on the public sector, as far as the provision of pathology services is concerned. The reason they will not address that point is that they know the facts in this matter are absolutely compelling. They involve income reductions of up to 30 per cent. The administrative burdens cannot be coped with by the small laboratories or, given the size of the other end of the scale, by the large laboratories. I refer to the amount of paperwork that would be involved for such hospitals as the Westmead Hospital, the Austin Hospital and various others.

The Government cannot address its mind to what the Haematology Association or the National Venereology Council of Australia has to say, simply because the Minister found that the best tactic to win this debate was to go to Senator Coulter and say, `Here are the figures for the gross incomes of rotten pathologists. Why don't you get into them?'. That is why, when the Minister came in today to make his speech on this matter, instead of focusing on any of the facts that have been raised he led off with a discussion about Dr Edelsten and the rorts in pathology services, which those on this side of the chamber were attempting to have cleared up long before the Government was even prepared to get its act together on this matter. He knew that that was the way in. He knew that the way in to the Australian Democrats was to plead to the politics of envy, the politics of greed, the politics of division within this whole issue; not to address the public health issues, not to address the issue of the care of individual Australians, but to say, `I know the way into the Democrats' psyche: the politics of greed, the politics of envy, the politics which, at its most crude level, pitches one or two people, in terms of their gross professional incomes'-their gross incomes mark you-`against the actual question of public health issues and the health care of individual Australians'. That can always be relied upon in the Australian Democrats: if one can find the little niche to exploit the politics of envy and the politics of greed, which the Democrats are on about all the time, one will always be able to get them. One will be able to demonstrate once again that the Australian Democrats are not a political party to be bought; they are a group of people to be rented by the hour. Having found their price on this occasion, the Government has exploited it to maximum advantage.
