TALK.START.PARA: —I had not proposed to involve myself in this part of the Committee debate, but my attention was drawn to Senator Walsh's rather infelicitous opening of the debate in this chamber on 29 November when, apart from being extremely rude about the speeches which had preceded his, he went on to refer to the amendment which was to be moved by the Opposition in the Committee of the Whole regarding the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It says that the Senate `reaffirms the resolution of 2 December' and so on, and `requires the Minister for Finance' to do this, that and so on. I repeat that this is not just a question of government policy. It is a question of the Constitution. The Senate does not determine its appropriations, nor does the House of Representatives, per se, determine its appropriations. Only Ministers of the Crown are constitutionally authorised to put requests to the Governor-General appropriating money. So the Senate can carry as many resolutions as it likes.

The reason I want to make some comment about that is that it seems to me, quite apart from anything else, that it is very unhelpful when the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) takes up an area where there has been extensive bipartisan consideration of the issues involved, and bipartisan acceptance of an approach which should be adopted to deal with the real possibility of conflict between the Executive Government and the Parliament on this vital question of the funding of Parliament. The Minister at the table, Senator Walsh, knows, or should know, that the Senate Appropriations and Staffing Committee has, in the years that it has been established, always carefully taken into account the Government's financial requirements. In other words, the general budgetary approach laid down by the Government has been very carefully taken into account by the Committee in its consideration, and on a regular basis there have been negotiations between the Department of Finance and the parliamentary departments, and this has all gone back through the Committee and so on. There has been in most cases a pretty amicable settling on figures which are reasonable from the point of view of the Parliament and reasonable from the point of view of the Government.

I think it is known to all senators that this year there was a rather pre-emptory approach on the part of the Department of Finance. I do not have the material in front of me and I have not refreshed my memory on it, but as I recall it, the Department of Finance and the Minister left us in a position where the Senate may well have to seek supplementary funding in the appropriations early next year.

The point I want to make now is that if Senator Walsh is going to take this macho and highly unpleasant and confrontationist approach, which he adopted at the commencement of this debate, I think he is being extremely unwise. I wish to say to the Minister that that is not the way to facilitate the dealing of these Appropriation Bills, whether in Committee or elsewhere. Nor is it a very sensible approach, given the difficulties that there are in bringing together the constitutional point made by the Minister, which relates to the control of executive Government over what matters are brought into the Parliament which will approve expenditure, and, as against that, the desirable constitutional principle that the Parliament should not just be the cat's paw of the Executive. The fact of the matter is that Labor, National, Democrat and Liberal senators have considered the issues that the Minister addressed in such a pre-emptory and unpleasant way last night. What we have done is to arrive at procedures which involve a degree of goodwill and cooperation between the Executive and the Parliament. The need for that is pretty apparent. The fact is that the Government has certain constitutional powers, but so does the Parliament. The Government cannot get its appropriations without the consent and support of the Senate and the House of Representatives. It would be, in my view, inflammatory and silly-childish would probably be the best word-for me to come into this place and start thumping the table and pointing out to the Minister that we have undoubted constitutional responsibilities and powers, and they include the power to refuse to pass the Minister's legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be very silly if you had a look at today's polls; very silly.

—I am perfectly happy to face Senator Walsh at the polls any time he likes, because I think we have had enough results this year to know that his government would be thrashed, and that the people of Australia are thoroughly sick of the contemptuous, arrogant way that Ministers, such as Minister Walsh, behave. I am simply trying to raise in this place and issue--
—You would be silly to do it.

—It is good to see a combative instinct in the senator for the Australian Capital Territory, Senator McMullan, but I suggest he show his more usual commonsense and consider the substance of the issues that I am trying to address. The fact of the matter is that the Minister, as part of the Executive Government, is an essential part in the chain of providing funds for any public purpose, including the operation of the Parliament, but so is this chamber and the House of Representatives. At the moment the position is that there is an all-party agreed position, reflected in the earlier Senate resolution, which arose from careful all-party consideration of this issue, which is based on both sides showing some commonsense and give and take. In other words, neither the Government nor the Parliament stands on its dignity and its high horse and says, `Since we have an element of constitutional power, we must have the final and total say'. If the Minister is saying that the Hawke Government is disallowing the approach which was laid down in that, as I understand it, unanimous recommendation of this chamber, which has been acted upon in the past and which this Minister now seems to wish to flout, I think he should be quite plain on that, because I think that poses a matter which is going to have to be attended to by the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want there to be any misunderstanding about this. I am not standing here and saying to the Minister that we would not pass the Appropriation Bills, because that would be a disproportionate response to the Minister's petulence, rudeness and flouting of the matters--

TALK.START.PARA: —And most of all because you would not be game. You would feel the wrath of the electorate.

—This is typical of Senator Walsh. He will no doubt be complaining later about the fact that the Appropriation Bills have not been passed. The fact is that he has failed to bring these Bills forward for consideration in a timely way. That is not of our making. That is the making of the Government. He now cannot resist employing his usual bullying and rude manner to advance his point. That cuts no ice with the Opposition and I do not intend to respond in kind as there does not seem to be much point. I am glad to see that Senator Macklin is here for the Australian Democrats, because I want to make the point-and it is the point which, incidentally, was made last night by Senator Peter Baume, who spoke in the debate immediately after Senator Walsh-that if the Minister is going to adopt this rather childish standover tactic then clearly this is a matter which the Senate will need to address and I do not believe that we will be able to address it in any final, complete or proper form in this debate. I think we will need to look at the mechanisms which have been adopted, we thought on a unanimous basis, to see what substitute mechanisms are available to prevent the rape of the Parliament, the destruction of the independence of the Parliament by this or any other Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: In a number of intemperate outbursts over the years Senator Walsh has made it clear that, at least on his bad days, he would be prepared to use the financial power of government to limit the Parliament's capacity to carry out its constitutional functions. I speak purely from memory and the Minister may wish to correct me on some point of detail, but my recollection is that Senator Walsh, for example, has on at least one occasion suggested that he or the Government could prevent the Senate undertaking some committee inquiry or at least limit the capacity of the Senate to undertake a committee inquiry that was desired by the majority of senators by the use of that same financial power. I mention that because the capacity of this Parliament to undertake its constitutional functions is a matter of long term importance for this country. It is a fundamental part of the democratic structure under which we operate.

I ask Senator Walsh to bear in mind that we are not just dealing with a fight between political parties, which he thoroughly enjoys, we are not just dealing with matters which go to the re-election, or non re-election, of the Hawke Government, but we are actually going to the basic institutional arrangements. While it is true that I can stand here and say all the things that I think are totally distasteful, disgusting, arrogant and so on about the Hawke Government and Senator Walsh can stand up and fulminate about the inadequacies of the Opposition as he perceives it, that is not the issue here. The issue here is the extent to which these two elements of our constitutional structure can simply ride roughshod one over the other. I think this is a matter to which I would hope the Minister would give sober consideration, that he would carefully examine the considerable amount of work that has been done by the Senate to arrive at a satisfactory resolution of the potential conflict between those two constitutional structures and that he might, in a more measured, considered and careful way, advise the Senate precisely where the Government stands on this matter.

If the Government stands where Senator Walsh's recent behaviour and recent words indicate-that is, if the Government believes that it has the right simply to ignore the views of the Parliament itself and simply to impose whatever financial regime it wishes on the Parliament-if the Government is casting aside the rather cooperative arrangements which involved a recognition of the mutual constitutional responsibilities of both the Parliament and the Executive, I think that should be explicit. It would then be incumbent on us to look at what options are available to the Senate-not in the full forum of the Committee of the Whole or of the Senate chamber itself but in some form of committee examination-to ensure that its constitutional position is properly protected. I suggest to the Minister that he remove this particular issue from the hurly-burly, if you like, of day to day political debate and look at it as a matter of important principle, which the Opposition certainly believes it to be.

In terms of our dealing with the balance of the Committee debate on the Appropriation Bills, I remind the Minister that there are some quite significant and difficult areas which I am sure will attract some debate. The Minister will be aware that in at least one case there is a very serious dissenting report on part of one of the Estimates committees in particular relating to the maladministration by this Government of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I simply suggest to the Minister that if we are to conclude our debate on these matters in some reasonable order, a higher level of civility than has been evident at the beginning of the debate would be very helpful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended entering this debate but as a result of the comments made last night by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, I wish to speak to the motion moved by the Opposition in the Committee of the Whole on the reaffirmation of the resolution of 2 December 1985 and indicate that the Australian Democrats will certainly support this. We supported it in 1985 and we believe it should provide the continuing basis for operations. I am certainly pleased to hear the points raised by the President and I hope that an amicable and settled relationship might ensue from the processes that are being undertaken at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that another parliament which this Parliament helped to establish-the Parliament of Papua New Guinea-has, within the last six weeks, changed its own Constitution in order to take total control of the appropriation of the Parliament into the Parliament itself and away from the Executive. Obviously it has been meeting the same types of problems that we have within the Westminster system and has settled them in a rather dramatic way. In future the entire appropriations process for Parliament in Papua New Guinea will be carried out by the Parliament with no consultation whatsoever with the Executive. I think that would be inappropriate in Australia. I think that it is far better that we proceed in the way that we have in the past-on the basis of consultation between the two groups.

Obviously the outlay for the Parliament is fairly substantial and should fit into the overall budgetary context. I think it would be inappropriate for that amount of money to be simply a floating amount over which there was no possible determination or tie into other obviously needed areas of public administration. Likewise, I believe that the amounts of money being provided for the operation of Parliament, when put against the amounts required for the operation of the Executive, are not large. If we are determined to continue with a parliamentary structure, obviously there will have to be some type of development of the parliamentary structure. One that has taken place in the last few years has been the operation of parliamentary committees. But I foresee that, in a matter of years, there will be other types of developments, particularly those types of developments that have taken place within the last 10 years in the United States Congress, where certain specialised groups have been established-for example, a budgetary office. Such groups would allow the Parliament to have access to detailed information which has not been, and seemingly will not be, provided by executives to Parliament.

If we are to have a parliamentary system of government, parliaments need information. If that information which has been collected by the Executive wing of government is not provided to Parliament, Parliament itself must seek to gather that information. I think a far better, cheaper and more rational way would be for the Executive to share with the Parliament the type of information base that it has. To date, that has not occurred and it seems unlikely to occur in the future. I believe that the development which the US Congress had to engage in, for precisely the same reasons, that is, its Executive refused to share information with it, forced it into taking action that led to considerable increases in costs in developing material twice. The Executive can continue on an exercise, I suppose, in our parliamentary system because it has a majority in the House of Representatives and feels, therefore, that it is secure.

Because of the likely disposition of groups within this Parliament, the Budget of the government of the day will always be passed. While my Party has the balance of power in the Senate, the Budget of the government of the day will always be passed. But that I do not think is the point, and I really do not believe that that is where the discussion ought to be. Rather, I believe the discussion should be about whether the parliamentary structures will be effective in our governmental system, or whether they will be increasingly marginalised, as they have been over many years. That might be inevitable; that might be the way in which we develop as a nation. It is not the way I would like our nation to develop, but that may be the way we go. While we are still a parliamentary democracy and while we are still spending considerable amounts of money on the operation of the Parliament, I believe that its functions and roles ought to be recognised and developed. One of its roles is scrutiny of the Executive's operations. That cannot be done without knowledge and information. For example, it cannot be done without at least a comparable computer system to the one that junior base grade clerks are using in almost every executive department throughout this nation. Without sophisticated equipment the job the Parliament is supposed to be doing will be merely one of rhetoric, one of show, and one which does not have any substance. If that is the way the majority wants to go, that is the way we will go. I think it would be a pity.

I think the parliamentary system has a lot of kick in it yet. I hope that it does. I believe that the only way it can be developed in a developing world-it cannot stand still; if it stands still it will go backwards-is to move forward in a way that will enhance the operation of individual members of parliament. I know that that is not necessarily something that executives or even opposition executives hoping to get into government, might like, but it is part of the genius of the system we have adopted. Unless we can come up with another system that protects the interests of individuals, I believe we ought to continue with the one we have at the moment.

I speak with some warmth on this because I come from a State where the parliamentary system has been abused, denigrated and in fact destroyed. The parliamentary system does not work in my State of Queensland and I think that is the direct reason that we are seeing enormous amounts of corruption in that State. In a correctly operating system that has public accounts committees and that has a Parliament which gets to see the Bills before they are debated-which does not occur in the Queensland Parliament-and which is able to overview the entire operation of executive government we have a check which is effective. As one Opposition speaker said in the second reading debate on the Appropriation Bills, the system has shown itself to be effective at the Federal level. That is the genius of the system we have adopted. If we are to continue with it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, could you make explicit whether you agree or disagree with the comments that I made about our need to get either a sensible approach to this or some re-examination of it?

—I think I have already indicated that our preference is to continue with the resolution of 2 December. The items that the President has now tabled will provide us with a firm base on which to proceed down that path. But it will require cooperation from the Executive to achieve that result. If the Executive is unwilling to achieve that result, I think we will simply get into a brawl which will not benefit either the Executive or the Parliament. I think it can be done through cooperation. I think these things were dealt with in a relatively robust fashion in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Appropriations and Staffing.
—You are in agreement with this?

—I am in agreement with this, and I think this is the way in which we ought to proceed. I am worried about the comments made last night by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). Having listened to them, it seems, to me at least, that the Government does not intend to cooperate with the Parliament to come to a sensible, reasonable solution. I would have hoped that that would have been the way in which we could proceed in an area where otherwise there could end up being a stand-off which would not benefit either the Parliament or the Executive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was pleased to hear the President make the comments he did to the extent that he restated the principles of the resolution because, without embracing the resolution, the problem of who ultimately makes the determinations in respect to the global amounts is not overcome.
—There is no problem about that; it is perfectly clear.

—The Minister's views are perfectly clear to him. As far as the Minister is concerned, that is where it will rest, and that is a problem we have right now, or at least it is going to be a problem he will have. The level and degree to which government is accountable to Parliament and the capacity which Parliament has to scrutinise the conduct of government ought not to be dictated exclusively by economic determinations of the government of the day. To create that nexus, in my view, places in the hands of a government the right to determine the degree to which governments are able to be scrutinised. Surely no reasonable person would support that proposition. From time to time there are those who judge Parliament to be the forum for oppositions, not for the representatives of all people. Not only oppositions ought to be scrutinising the conduct of government but all members of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, the funding of the parliamentary departments goes to the very heart of the system of government that we have in Australia. Of course, without question, the level of funding dictates to a very large degree the capacity and ability of Parliament to fulfil its obligations and its functions. If funding is less than adequate and less than reasonable, the Parliament's constitutional capacity to monitor, scrutinise and judge the Government's conduct and its legislation fails. Under Senator Walsh's proposal, the Government could ultimately choke off funding to the degree that it would be almost impossible for the Parliament to begin to scrutinise, in an effective way, the conduct of Government. Senator Chaney's memory is quite correct; Senator Walsh threatened the Senate with removing funding to the point where a committee could not fulfil its obligations.

I want for a moment to touch upon the correspondence which I suspect was included in that tabled by the President. Before I do so, let me say this: the present appropriation and staffing system we have and the resolution that was ultimately brought down by Estimates Committee A in 1985 were a result of a 1981 report of the Select Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, which was set up in 1980. That Committee was chaired, if I am correct, by Senator Jessop. It included members of the Democrats and, of course, members of the Labor Party, the Labor Party's representative being former Senator Douglas McClelland, who was very proud of the Committee's determinations and deliberations. It was he, I think, who reminded Sir Billy Snedden of the role that Committee had played in setting up a system of funding for government departments. The resolution of that Committee in 1981 was carried unanimously. If anybody examined the Hansard records they would find that nobody from the present Government, including Senator Walsh, rose to object to that fundamental principle in the same way as the present motion--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was as meaningless then as it is now in the final analysis.

—Senator Walsh chose to remain silent on that occasion and he chose to remain silent in 1985. He had his feet in his mouth when the resolution of Estimates Committee A was carried unanimously and when the Appropriations and Staffing Committee reported. That Committee was made up of all parties and included the independents. It had on it the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, who presumably agreed with the resolution and the correspondence that flowed from it as he was a member of it. He did not dissent from the resolution at the Committee hearing or in the chamber. That resolution was carried in the Parliament unanimously without an utterance from Senator Walsh. He certainly did not record a contrary vote. Senator Walsh saying that the motion before us is as worthless as the resolution passed in 1981 indicates a contempt that he has for this chamber and is a reflection of his present attitude. Let me remind the Committee of the resolution that was carried in 1985 by Estimates Committee A, which was chaired by Senator Graham Richardson. It said, inter alia:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the estimates of expenditure for the Senate to be included in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill shall be those determined by the Standing Committee on Appropriations and staffing.
There was no dissent from that proposition or from the rest of the resolution. The resolution stated:

(c) if before the introduction of the Bill the Minister for Finance should, for any reason, wish to vary the details of the estimates determined by the Committee he should consult with the President of the Senate with a view to obtaining the agreement of the Committee to any variation . . .

If my memory serves me correctly, the first correspondence the Committee received on this matter was dated 1 August. On 1 August it received the first correspondence warning of dissatisfaction with the arrangements that had been made and the direction in which the appropriations were going. My understanding is that Senator Walsh's departmental officers, who had had consultations up until that time, had given no indication-and I am sure the President of the Senate will tell me if I am wrong-that there was any unhappiness in general terms with the estimates. The resolution further stated:

(d) in the event of agreement not being reached between the President and the Minister, then the Leader of the Government in the Senate, as a member of the Appropriations and Staffing Committee, be consulted . . .
Of course, Senator Walsh did not consult Senator Button. It is not on the public record. The resolution stated further:

(e) the Senate acknowledges that in considering any request for the Minister for Finance the Committee and the Senate would take into consideration the relevant expenditure and staffing policies of the Government of the day . . .
of course, that has been more than done by any measure-

(f) in turn the Senate expects the Government of the day to take into consideration the role and responsibilities of the Senate which are not of the Executive Government and which may at times involve conflict with the Executive Government.

The Government, in my view, has not done that. There is no indication that Senator Walsh has a serious care or concern for the responsibilities and functions of the Parliament. Yet I am sure that he, as much as anybody, took advantage, when the present Government was in opposition, of the various select and standing committees, drew for sustenance upon the intellectual input into the Parliamentary Library and the various functions and services of Hansard, and used for his best endeavours all the facilities available as a result of the consideration of the appropriations. The first letter that the President received was from Senator Walsh, dated 1 August, which commenced:
I am writing to you concerning the 1988-89 estimates for the Parliamentary Departments submitted recently to my Department.

To my understanding, that was the first indication that the Committee had that there were problems. So concerned were the President and the Speaker with discharging their proper responsibilities that they were moved on 5 August to write to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) seeking substantial and, presumably, moral support for their position on both the chambers, not the least being the Senate. But that was a wishful hope, that was a vain endeavour, because the Prime Minister wrote back no sooner than 29 August simply saying that he understood that the Minister for Finance was writing to the President to advise him of the Government's decision on funding for the Parliament for 1988-89. I wish to refer to two other pieces of correspondence. The first, from Senator Walsh, states his position, which is worth recording again. On 26 September Senator Walsh said:
In your letter you note that in dealing with the estimates I have not had regard to the procedures laid down in the Senate's resolution of 2 December 1985.

The letter referred to was written by the President and the Speaker, no doubt with feeling and commitment, saying that they noted that in dealing with the Estimates Senator Walsh did not have regard for the procedures laid down in the Senate's resolution of 2 December, a copy of which was attached. Senator Walsh responded by saying:

You say also that you are firmly of the view that you are in the best position to determine an appropriate level of funding for the Parliament in consultation with your officers. As you would be aware it is the Government's prerogative to advise the Governor-General with respect to his recommendations concerning Appropriation Bills, pursuant to Section 56 of the Constitution. And, of course, it is the Government's responsibility also to raise the associated revenue. Given these responsibilities of the Executive, as Minister for Finance, I could not agree to a process whereby the Parliament was able to determine aggregate funding for its own purposes, particularly in the absence of adequate external considerations.

I wish that Senator Walsh had supported his conviction by voting against his own Party and motions that were supported by his own Party, but he chose instead to commit it to writing when dealing in particular with Appropriations. That letter from Senator Walsh ultimately, and quite properly, provoked a response from the President and from the Speaker. They said to Senator Walsh:

We wish to take the opportunity to place on record again a very significant point of principle which emerges from the letter. Although the development of the annual budget is at the initiative of the Executive, it is of course a responsibility of both Houses of Parliament to agree to any proposed appropriations.
That is a point that Senator Walsh seems to overlook. The letter went on:

It would be constitutionally anomalous for the appropriations of the Houses to be determined by the Executive Government which the Houses are supposed to scrutinize and hold accountable. It was for that reason that a separate Appropriation Bill for the Parliamentary Departments was introduced.
That flows from the unanimous recommendations of the Select Committee in 1981 of which members of the present government were then members. Senator Sibraa and Mrs Child said:

The balance between executive responsibility and the legislature's right to responsible financial independence is a delicate one. You will recall the conclusion reached by the Senate Select Committee on Appropriations and Staffing in 1981 that it is unacceptable for the Parliament to make bids for funds to which the Executive may apply a qualitative judgment and thereby restrict the ability of the legislature to discharge its constitutional duties.

That, frankly, goes to the very heart of this debate. This debate ought not to be simply and exclusively about the economic policies, economic directions or economic considerations as determined by Senator Walsh and the Government. As the Opposition concedes-of course I agree readily-they ought to be a consideration, but not exclusively. The matter has clearly been the exclusive determination of Senator Walsh. To put it in gentle terms, I find it regrettable that Senator Walsh has chosen, and presumably he reflects the views of the Government, to treat the Parliament and the Senate in particular with the contempt he has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, let me take the Senate through the history of this year's parliamentary departments bids and appropriations. The bids were received late in July-I think it was the twentieth; it was certainly around that day-which was three weeks late. The Presiding Officers were both overseas attending a presiding officers conference. As the President, Senator Sibraa, has just confirmed, they did not return until 31 July. That was about the time at which the Budget was supposed to be put to bed. It was in fact put to bed early in August. I also interpolate here that the rate of expenditure growth, even after one has abstracted the fact that there has been a move into a new and more expensive Parliament House, in the parliamentary departments has been in excess of that of the Public Service generally and in excess of that in just about every other portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: As the President's statement indicated, consultations will be held at an earlier date next year. The Government and officials will consult on this. There have been more extensive consultations in the past when the bids have been received at a more timely moment and when the Presiding Officers have been in the country. Those consultations will take place and I welcome the likelihood of their starting earlier next year. But the final decisions on the Appropriation Bills that are put to Parliament and on the contents of those Appropriation Bills are made by the Executive. Last night I spelt out the constitutional facts behind that. If the Opposition finds them distasteful, that is not my fault. Perhaps if it finds them distasteful enough it should do something about amending the Constitution.

—Does the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade agree that the Yugoslav Government should give a full, unconditional and public apology for the shooting of Joseph Tokic, should offer compensation to the wounded boy and should provide complete cooperation with police inquiries, coupled with a waiver of diplomatic immunity, should immunity apply to the person responsible for the shooting? Does he further agree that unless these steps are immediately taken by the Yugoslav Government, the Australian Government should close the Sydney Consulate and expel its staff?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can advise the Senate what the state of play is on this matter. I think that might be the best way of approaching Senator Chaney's question. The Yugoslav security guard who was involved in Sunday's shooting incident was interviewed at 4 p.m. yesterday by the New South Wales police at the Yugoslav consulate-general and in the presence of the Consul-General. A further interview has been sought for later today at which time the weapon from which the shots were fired will be inspected by the police. This interview process follows advice given by the Yugoslav Ambassador on Monday that his Government had agreed that the person involved in Sunday's shooting incident would be made available for interview by the New South Wales police at the consulate-general and in the presence of the Consul-General, and that the pistol from which the shots were fired would be made available for inspection by the New South Wales police also at the consulate-general and in the presence of the Consul-General. The Ambassador also advised my Department that we could strictly rule out any question of the security guard involved endeavouring to leave Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of immunity which Senator Chaney raised, I repeat the advice which I have already given to the Senate-no question of diplomatic or consular immunity for the security guard concerned has been raised by the Yugoslav authorities with the Government. Our handling of the matter continues to proceed on the basis that no such immunity exists. Perhaps I should say in further clarification of this point that the matter of immunity is determined both by provisions of the 1963 Vienna Convention on Consular Relations and also agreement by both governments as to the level or status of the particular officer at the post concerned. Immunity can be waived by the sending government but it cannot be altered unilaterally by the host government. It is essentially a matter for determination by the courts in accordance with the applicable law as to whether someone enjoys immunity. I repeat: in this case no claim of immunity, diplomatic or consular, has been made. It does not appear, I suppose, likely to be made at this stage, which should avoid at least that complication arising.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he have the right to remain silent?

—He has the same right as any other person appearing before the courts, as I would have thought Senator Alston would appreciate as a once-upon-a-time practising lawyer. Accordingly, as I have just said, while there would not appear to be any question arising about personal immunity in this case, at least on the basis of what has been put to us so far, it is the case that the consular premises are themselves, in effect, immune from physical access except with the consent of and on conditions set by the consulate. This has the potential to place obstacles in the way of the law taking its normal course in this case.

ANSWER.PARA: The Ambassador has, in his discussions with departmental deputy secretaries handling this case, offered, as I have previously said publicly, every possible cooperation in resolving this matter. So far that cooperation has been reasonably forthcoming from the Consul-General but there are signs, I have to say, that that willingness is diminishing. The Government is continuing to follow the situation very closely and is considering the available action we can take.

With that in mind and against that background, the Ambassador was called in this morning to the Department of Foreign Affairs and told the following: first, that if, when the police have completed their interviews and reviewed the available evidence, they determine that there is a basis on which a prosecution should proceed we would expect the Consulate-General to surrender the person concerned to enable the law to take its course and, secondly, if this did not occur, seriously adverse consequences for the bilateral relationship must be expected to follow. We are currently considering all available options in this respect. I would not care to be more precise than that at this stage as to what those available options might be, but they certainly include the option to which Senator Chaney has referred. The Ambassador has said that he would report these two important points to his Government is Belgrade.

It continues to be a recurring theme of the Yugoslav response to these events that the response of the Australian Protective Service to incidents in the past and to the demonstration on the weekend has been and was less than satisfactory. That is not a charge that we accept. I have received a report from my Department on this matter. I expect that the Ambassador will be called in, either this evening or tomorrow morning-we are still in the process of assembling a little further information, so I cannot be precise about the time-to be presented with a formal note in response to the issues his Government has raised. In this respect, whatever the situation might be with respect to the police presence and involvement at the demonstration, it remains the Government's very strong position that no use of firearms was conceivably justified by anything that occurred on the weekend and our whole course of response has been governed by that.

I think there was one other aspect of Senator Chaney's question, concerning apology and compensation. As yet that has not been formally pursued by the Australian Government. We are waiting, among other things, for a police report on the incident, a police decision as to the course that they want to follow and a fuller account of the actual circumstances of the shooting. Of course an apology is appropriate, is called for and has not yet been forthcoming. That is one of the things that is not assisting a speedy resolution of this matter. The question of requests or claims for compensation is something that we will certainly address at an appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his very full reply which I think, whilst lengthy, was warranted given the seriousness of the matter that the Minister was addressing. I ask him, firstly, whether he can confirm that what he has told the Senate means that the steps that are being followed can lead in the normal way to a prosecution subject only to the problem of access, which the Minister touched on in his reply. Secondly, can the Minister confirm that the range of measures being considered by the Government include those raised in my question?
—I thought I had made both those points clear in my answer. The answer is yes on both counts.

—Has the Minister for Consumer Affairs seen an article in Australian Business which reports the concerns of certain advertising industry associations about changes being made to consumer and community participation in industry self-regulation? What are the Minister's views on the need for public participation in the regulation of this industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article. I was particularly concerned about an allegation made in the article that there was a division between the Government and the Trade Practices Commission in respect of this area. I am somewhat surprised by the article and some of the comments that have been attributed to representatives of the Advertising Federation of Australia Ltd and the Australian Association of National Advertisers. It is fair to say that for about two years there has been a common need for the self-regulatory system of the advertising industry to be opened up to public and consumer participation. Even the industry itself has noted in recent days that its current performance is not going all that well. I quote one particular industry spokesperson:

ANSWER.PARA: Many of the values that advertising agencies continue to purvey on behalf of their clients are yesterday's values. Many of their morals are yesterday's morals, and many of their methods are yesterday's methods.

The basic position the Government accepts in this area is that self-regulation of the advertising industry, both in the drawing up of its codes and its complaints structures, is something to be pursued and accepted. We believe that self-regulation can be flexible and efficient but we also believe it needs to be more credible. It needs in that process to ensure adequate retention of public confidence and adequate involvement of consumer and community participation. The Trade Practices Tribunal recently noted the need for that sort of concept.

The credibility of the Advertising Council in the community is very much an important benchmark. To achieve and maintain credibility there needs to be effective representation of people who have access to and have the advice and expertise offered by some of the various consumer and community groups. It is not a radical proposal. It is one that operates quite extensively overseas. In New Zealand public members are in the majority on the Advertising Standards Council. Europe and Canada also have councils which allow for great public participation in the development of standards. In the case of Canada there is a system of wide consultation.

I do not believe that the attitudes expressed in the Australian Business magazine article by those representatives of the industry are the views of the most responsible members of the advertising industry. Most of them accept the need to greatly improve public participation. At the same time it should be said that if that is to happen there needs to be greater responsibility shown by consumer and community groups in order that they may be able to make a more responsible and constructive contribution to the development of the code and its implementation.

In closing, I should say that the Government's view is that industry will respond to the needs for increased participation and will reject this counter productive hostility which appears in articles such as the Australian Business magazine article to which Senator Devereux referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Has the Minister seen documents obtained by American veterans under that country's freedom of information laws which indicate extremely widespread use during the Vietnam war of the previously unreported herbicide known as super orange? Is the Minister aware of communications between military commanders at the time of the conflict which outline methods by which the herbicide could be used extensively in all areas, including built-up areas, while announcing the opposite to placate the fears of, to use their words, the `peasants'? What is the chemical makeup of super orange, where was it used and how much was used? Finally, did the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam consider super orange in its deliberations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister Humphreys has advised me that he has not seen the documents referred to by Senator McLean. Presumably the honourable senator has seen them. Mr Humphreys would appreciate it if the honourable senator would make them available to him. He has asked me to advise the honourable senator that, considering that the war in South Vietnam extended over more than 10 years, it is not especially helpful to refer simply to `communications at the time of the conflict'. Senator McLean may have been referring in the second part of his question to policy suggestions made to the United States Chief of Staff in November 1967, but it would help if Senator McLean could be a little more specific.

ANSWER.PARA: As mentioned in response to the first part of Senator McLean's question, the Minister has not seen the documents and the references to super orange. The formulation code-named herbicide orange 2 is certainly referred to in the Evatt report. It should be possible to determine whether super orange is the same as herbicide orange 2 or a totally different herbicide, after Senator McLean has made the documents available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is important that I clarify the essence of the answer, considering the assurances that I was given several days ago of the close monitoring of these matters by the Department. —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Some groups in Tasmania have expressed reservations on the 790,000 tonnes increase in sustained yield in the agreement with Tasmania announced yesterday. Has the Minister any comment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Devlin for his question, because it is a question that has arisen in some of the press commentary that followed yesterday's announcement by the Prime Minister, Senator Richardson and myself on behalf of the Commonwealth Government and by Premier Gray and Mr Groom on behalf of the Tasmanian Government.

—Since the interjections from honourable senators opposite indicate some interest in this general matter, I should say that, as a result of the package of things agreed yesterday morning, 262,000 hectares of Tasmanian forest will now be jointly nominated by the Tasmanian Government and the Commonwealth Government for World Heritage listing. That will bring to 1,031,355 the number of hectares for World Heritage nomination from Tasmania. That in itself is a significant and outstanding achievement by this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the question that Senator Devlin has raised: there has been, as Senator Devlin said, some scepticism-one may even say some cynicism-about how the 790,000 additional resource tonnes were calculated, given that in 1985 an environmental impact statement came to a different conclusion. I should point out that the process of assessing available wood resources is a complex and continuing job. It is not an issue that focuses on one time and freezes at that point; it is an ongoing matter. The investigation, in proving up this additional 790,000 tonnes, involved a further thorough analysis, including a review of aerial photography, on-site visits, re-runs of data through computers to check comparisons, comparisons with previous inquiries and records, and scrupulous recalculation of data.

The final figures were checked by officials of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Department in respect of which I share ministerial responsibility with Mr Kerin, and also by officials in Senator Richardson's Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Both groups are satisfied that the extra resource is in fact available. We have nothing to hide on this, and, in order to provide the information that some of the questioners have sought, I now wish to table a document from my Department which goes through the calculations, providing the information and the tonnages at each point.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Will the Minister confirm that the National Crime Authority (NCA) has identified 56 persons to be investigated by the Authority for alleged organised crime and official corruption in South Australia, pursuant to the new terms of reference? Will the Minister advise whether he, or the Attorney-General, discussed with the NCA the proposed list of persons to be investigated, and were any names raised by the NCA not included? As the NCA obviously has material justifying the investigation for serious crime of these 56 persons, will the Minister confirm that the relevant South Australian Ministers and the South Australian Commissioner of Police have, prior to the granting of these terms of reference, been kept fully informed of the allegations and evidence in support of such allegations? Lastly, prior to the granting of the terms of reference, had the NCA requested investigation by the South Australian authorities of the allegations against any of the 56 named persons, and have such investigations been carried out to the satisfaction of the NCA?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I will not confirm any particular number of persons as being the subject or targets of the National Crime Authority investigation to be undertaken in South Australia in accordance with the terms of reference which I provided to this chamber yesterday. It is never the case that names, or in this case numbers, of persons the subject of the terms of reference are identified. Hence, many of the questions which flowed from that initial question I do not intend to answer.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the role of the South Australian Ministers, particularly the Attorney-General-and, of course, the Acting Attorney-General over the last week or so following the sudden illness of Mr Chris Sumner-and the role of the Commissioner of Police, what has to be understood is that, before the National Crime Authority can obtain a reference from the Intergovernmental Committee of Ministers, an assurance has to be given to that intergovernmental committee in accordance with the statute that the South Australian police cannot cope with this particular investigation by using ordinary police methods. That obviously involves an assessment by the Commissioner of Police and advice to his Minister, who then advises the intergovernmental committee of that fact. So there has been quite a deal of assessment of the situation by the Commissioner of Police and the South Australian Ministers; hence their advice to the intergovernmental committee, which was accepted, that ordinary police methods pursued by the South Australian police could not satisfactorily resolve the allegations made in that State of corruption and serious crime. What was the honourable senator's final question?

TALK.START.PARA: —Have the South Australian authorities been investigating these matters to the satisfaction of the NCA?

—I have tried to indicate the role of the South Australian Commissioner of Police in relation to these matters. The National Crime Authority is now well poised to go into South Australia as soon as this Parliament passes the required amendment to the legislation. Immediately upon that happening, the additional member will be appointed. Counsel assisting, and the various teams of seconded police officers, accountants and lawyers, will then move into premises in South Australia and commence the investigations.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The part of the question which was not answered by the Minister was my request that the Minister advise whether he or the Attorney-General discussed with the NCA the proposed list of persons to be investigated, and whether any names raised by the NCA were not included in the list.

—I certainly have not been made aware of any names in relation to this reference. That is not the normal practice. The practice is that the Minister requesting the reference and the National Crime Authority come to an agreement as to the targets and as to the names of the persons to be the subject of a particular reference. Therefore, I am unable to say what happened in the interplay between those two entities. Assurances and indications were given by the South Australian Minister at the meeting of the intergovernmental committee and in the Parliament of South Australia about the full cooperation being offered by that Government. I know that Mr Justice Stewart and the members of the Authority, and indeed, the new member, would not want to be in any way circumscribed or hampered, or in any way set up in a sense, whereby they could not undertake the fullest possible investigation by having a circumscribed list and names omitted. I cannot believe that the National Crime Authority would undertake this reference without it being confident that it had the fullest possible scope within which to resolve the matter successfully.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce concerned about Opposition criticism in regard to partnership for development agreements? Are these agreements an essential element of a strategy to boost the level of research and development in Australia and the export of such information equipment as computers and computer software? In relation to the criticism from the Opposition, can the Minister inform the Senate whether the latest export and research and development figures indicate that the partnership schemes have been a success?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not particularly concerned about the Opposition criticisms because, by and large, they have been ill-informed. I welcome any interest in the matter, because I think it is important. It is too early to say that this program has been a success, but there are some very encouraging signs in relation to it.

ANSWER.PARA: At the tenth annual general meeting of the Australian Information Industry Association (AIIA), held in Sydney on Friday, 25 November, that organisation, which is the industry association of all the major companies, released its annual data collection on the performance of its member companies. In relation to exports and research and development, the Australian Information Industry Association's members reported exports of information goods and services worth $323m up to 30 June of this year, an increase of 60 per cent on the figures for the previous year. Furthermore, overall investment, including research and development expenditure or investment, was valued at $102m, which is an increase of 26 per cent on figures for the previous year. Member companies are also forecasting a further increase in excess of 13 per cent in the coming financial year.

It is worth noting, in view of some of the misguided criticisms, that the exports were specifically measured in terms of Australian value-added activity and excluded any re-exporting activities. The Australian Information Industry Association has indicated that the industry is confident that exports will exceed $1.4 billion by 1994. Research and development investment will approach $500m annually by 1994, consistent with the targets established by the Government's information industry strategy which I released in September 1987.

It seems clear that the industry has taken to heart the main point of the information industry's strategy and its focus on exports, research and development and local value-added activity. It is also clear that the strategy's emphasis on broadening the range of exported goods and services has been taken to heart by the industry, with the AIIA reporting an increase in service exports of over 130 per cent. One is able to say at this time that it is clear that the industry is rising to the challenge of the strategy. This early indication of success is very welcome. The industry does not appear confused about the direction and mechanisms of the Government information industry strategy. That confusion appears to reside elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, follows the dorothy dix question that he has just answered on the information industry and its exports, and his comment that the Opposition was ill-informed. Does the Minister deny that he caused some confusion about this area by giving conflicting answers to Estimates committees and to the Senate on the Australian content required in company exports under this scheme? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last part of the question is, not at all. The process of discussion with various companies about lifting levels of research and development and exports began in mid-1987, as I recall. There was quite a concerted effort from them to get companies to lift their game in this regard. It may be correct that only three major companies had signed partnership agreements as at February this year, but a considerably larger number had been subject to pre-qualified offset status agreements which date back some time, and had been involved in discussion with the Government about the strategy which was to be adopted.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to alleged confusion in an answer I gave to an Estimates committee, I invite Senator Chaney to look at the question as well as the answer. In the context of that discussion we were talking not only about local value-added activity but also about exports and research and development. If he finds the answer confused, so be it. One of Senator Lewis' complaints was that this is government by press release. But if we give answers at Question Time--

TALK.START.PARA: —The press release is about agreement--

—Look, Senator, there are numerous documents and announcements about the content of the strategy. Senator Lewis complained about what he called government by press release. On the the other hand, if we give long answers to these questions in the Senate at Question Time--
—We will always give you leave to make a statement, at any time you like.
—Thanks. If we give long answers at Question Time, the Opposition tends to nod off and complain about the issue.
—Stop scoring points and do something about the state of the industry.

—Senator Chaney now interjects and says, `Stop scoring points'. I am glad that I am scoring points. —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Since the industry is not here, I will have to ask the Minister. Why, in the light of the reply he has now given me, did he say in response to the earlier question that it was too early to say whether the program was a success?
—That was something which I can probably accurately characterise--
—I thought it was a moment of honesty.

—Senator Chaney interjects about that being honesty. I will get back to that. It may be fairly characterised as caution and undue modesty, because if the Opposition had ever, in its whole period in government, developed a program as successful as this one, we would have heard about it for years. I think that is a fair characterisation of it in the circumstances. Senator Chaney, with his great capacity for moral judgments about everybody else, wants to characterise it in terms of honesty. I do not do that. I think it has been a sensible program which is working pretty well. That is all I said. I do not want to go overboard about it because it is early days.
—Secret partnerships; that is what it is.

—Senator Lewis persists with the mindless interjections which have got him into all sorts of trouble in the past. If the Opposition wants to do a serious analysis of the partnership for development program, frankly I would not start with Senator Lewis.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is he aware that the Australian Democrats have decided to oppose the Government's decision to deregulate the domestic wheat market on condition that the needs of organic non-chemical wheat growers are satisfied under regulated arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware, as Senator Burns has asked me, of the Democrats position on wheat marketing. In fact, I am aware of it by virtue of a press release dated 26 November, embargoed until 8 p.m. on that day, under the hand of Senator Janet Powell. Senator Powell, in her press release, says that because the Democrats believe there is a position they can reach with the Wheat Marketing Board, to protect growers of organic or non-chemical wheat, therefore they will try to scuttle the move to a freer market, a deregulation of wheat marketing in Australia. This is a very interesting press release. It would repay some study by the coalition, because on the one hand she bags the Liberal Party for supporting the free market, and on the other hand she supports the National Party of Australia for supporting protection, and justifies the Democrats position on the basis of organic or non-chemical wheat.

ANSWER.PARA: However, let me answer the rest of Senator Burns's question. The fact that the current regulatory arrangements penalise innovation by growers, such as growing organic or non-chemical wheat, is one of the major reasons for the Government's decision to commercialise the domestic wheat market. But there is no way the current disincentive to innovation can be completely removed without deregulating the market. In short, the Democrats have set themselves an impossible task. They cannot support both the Australian Grain Council's desire for regulation and meet the needs of organic non-chemical growers. At present organic growers, and others like them, are forced to use the grower-to-buyer system. Just by explaining that system I can show how complex and expensive it is.

Under that system a grower contracts with a buyer-no traders are allowed. They agree on a margin above or below the administered domestic price and wheat is delivered, but the buyer pays the Wheat Board and not the grower for the wheat. The Wheat Board deducts for its pool, the administered domestic price, statutory levies, such as for research, and in most States a charge for the State bulk handling authorities, even though those authorities may not be used. The grower receives the agreed margin, less the statutory and bulk handling charges, plus the normal pool payments; that is, the guaranteed minimum price and any subsequent payments. The problem is that the grower has, in effect, paid for two sets of services not used-the Wheat Board's interest and marketing costs, which are deducted from pool returns based on the calculations of the gross national product and the bulk handling authority charge.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition may not like any of this but I am determined to put my view. The Grains Council has suggested removing the bulk handling authority charge, which would improve the system somewhat, but it is only about $5 per tonne. As the Board's pool costs of about $12 per tonne and the restrictions on traders would remain, growers, such as those the Democrats seek to assist, would continue to be penalised. Whenever the Wheat Board has a monopoly on the domestic market and compulsorily acquires all wheat, organic growers and others like them must be penalised.

ANSWER.PARA: There are a great many growers who want the opportunity to choose who they sell to-41 per cent according to a recent survey. They are all being penalised by the current arrangements. By allowing for freedom of choice, competitive pressures will ensure that there is maximum efficiency in marketing, transport, distribution and handling. That will benefit the growers. I am not surprised that most of the chortling comes from the National Party while the Liberal Party remains quiet.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer the Minister to the fact that the application of the Canberra Montessori Society to establish a Montessori primary school has been rejected by the Government and the appeal is to be heard tomorrow by the Non-Government Schools Funding Committee. I ask the Minister whether he is aware that the appeal board Chairman was quoted in the Canberra Times of 24 November as saying, in part:

QUESTION.PARA: The opting out of public education by a sizeable section of the public could cause the irretrievable breakdown of the public school system.

She also said that `the changing relationship between public and private schools in Australia' was `a matter for concern'. Does the Minister believe it is appropriate for a person who, while commendably a supporter of a strong public school system, is clearly very opposed to non-government education, to be chairing a committee hearing an appeal from an organisation wishing to establish a non-government school?

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware of the quote attributed to the chairman of the Appeal Board, nor did I know that the Montessori application for a school had been rejected and was being appealed against. I am aware of the basis of the Commonwealth's policy for receiving applications for either new funding for schools or expanded funding, and that is principally the basis of need for additional capacity. I think it is generally agreed that it would be a waste of resources if additional private schools were to be built in an area where either the school population was declining or there was already more than enough capacity within the government system and perhaps some of the private school systems to provide for the population in that area. The need for capacity is the basic determinant of the Commonwealth policy and applications are graded into four different categories, and I believe that they are published. It really does not have anything to do with the preference for a public or private education system of anybody who sits on an appeal board because the criteria for selection into either the high, medium, low and very low categories-I think that is what they are called-are more objective than subjective judgments about whether the public or the private school system is preferable. I will refer that question to the Minister to see whether he has anything to add to what I have said.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I understand there are approximately 1,000 injuries a day and 550 deaths each year in Australian work places. Even allowing for 20 per cent of those deaths being due to accidents travelling to and from work, the figures are still terribly high and the cost to the economy is estimated at $6.5 billion a year. I note that the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission has identified six priority areas and is working towards the development of preventive strategies for these areas. I ask the Minister whether this action will be adequate to achieve a reduction in the unacceptably high level of occupational injury and death. Is there a need to target accident prevention and safety promotion as a priority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Crowley says in her question is true-Australia has an unacceptably high incidence of work-related death and injury. In industry, particularly, it affects productivity and it is unfortunate for those employees concerned. The Commonwealth holds responsibilities for areas under Commonwealth jurisdiction in this matter, including its own employees, but responsibility for occupational health and safety falls primarily under the jurisdiction of State and Territory governments. Each State and Territory has now introduced and administers legislation in the area which has been or is now being reviewed in most States. It was in an attempt to reverse the situation described in Senator Crowley's question and to bring about a concerted national approach to prevention that the Government established the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, which has made significant progress towards developing a national strategy in consultation with the States and other bodies. A major priority has been the development of national uniform data. There have been other studies on work-related fatalities and the Commission is also in the process of developing a wide range of national standards and codes of practice.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of duplication of effort is one of the reasons why the Commission made a decision to identify and develop preventive strategies to address the six priority areas referred to by Senator Crowley. These priority areas, which we frequently hear about, are back problems, hearing loss, skin disorders, chemical management, mechanical equipment injury and occupational cancer. In light of Senator Crowley's concern, which has been reflected in questions in the Senate on a number of occasions, there is a concern that these priorities may not adequately cover the problems faced by Australian employees. I will pursue the question with the Minister for Industrial Relations, including the possibility that this be taken up further in the relevant Commonwealth-State Ministers forum, and I will ask the Minister to inform Senator Crowley of progress in those discussions as soon as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: Whether the material originates in Australia or elsewhere, the usual requirements for import permits for micro-organisms will apply to deposits under the Treaty. the Patent Office does not keep figures which provide a breakdown of the number of applications for microorganisms themselves as distinct from applications involving the use of microorganisms. There have so far been about a dozen patent applications concerning genetically engineered animals, including cases where only a provisional specification has been lodged. Of the 6 applications which have reached the stage of being open to the public inspection, 2 applicants are from Australia, 1 from the United Kingdom, 2 from the United States and 1 from the Federal Republic of Germany.
These applications concern a variety of uses of farm animals or methods of producing them. They cover:
Production of an animal by introducing DNA using sperm as the carrier;
Harvesting useful proteins from the milk of the animal;
A method of changing the physical characteristics of an animal; and
A larger animal with better meat quality.
None of the applications for animals has yet been examined. Patents are unlikely to be granted in the next 18 months to 2 years assuming that the applications proceed along a normal path.
The length of term for all standard patents granted in Australia is 16 years. There is no difference in term between patents for biological and other inventions.

Progeny which fall within the scope of a patent's claims-that is, which have the essential characteristics of the patented strain-would prima facie be covered by the patent. They may not, however, be an infringement of the patent, depending on the circumstances. The Patents Act contains no provisions expressly dealing with the issue, so the position would depend on the terms under which breeding stock was sold by the patentee. In the absence of any case law which might invoke some kind of implied licence to breed progeny, both buyer and seller of breeding stock would be well advised to ensure that the terms of sale were clear on this point.

The usual requirements of the Patents Act apply to applications for patents for animals. There are no special requirements. Although a patent has not yet been granted in Australia for an animal, the Commissioner of Patents has informed me that the Patent Office would not refuse a patent for a new and non-human animal variety, provided the invention satisfied all the usual requirements of the Patents Act. Of course, the validity of a patent can only be finally determined by the courts.

The obligation to make a deposit only applies to microorganism inventions in certain circumstances. The Government has no plans to impose a deposit requirement in the case of animal patents generally, but if such a need were indeed to emerge it would be considered carefully.

In conclusion, I would observe that it would be a mistake if moral and ethical problems about animal experimentation and genetic engineering were to become focused upon the patent system when wider issues are involved. I wish to make a few observations about the patent system in this regard.

The main idea of the patent system is to offer encouragement to inventors, entrepreneurs and investors to make new advances in technology and to bring new products into the open and onto the market. The High Court has held that inventions which belong to the useful arts and have some economic significance are generally capable of patent protection. Patent law therefore has some inherent flexibility to cope with changing technology.

The law in general has always recognised that people can legitimately own and breed animals. It is consistent for patent law to permit a patent of an animal variety possessing new characteristics produced by the inventor.
Animal experimentation and genetic manipulation can take place whether or not patents are available. The patent system is and should be neutral on any ethical issues involved in such experiments.
The Patent Office would refuse any patent application for a human being.

The Defence Force retirement and death benefits (DFRDB) scheme has been much in the news lately, as honourable senators would be only too well aware. First of all, the numbers of servicemen who left the defence forces in the last financial year without any entitlement to pensions are as follows: in 1986-87, 448 officers left without entitlement to ongoing benefits. The 1986-87 Annual Report of the Authority reported concern as to the workload implications of a significant increase in the number of new invalidity cases received during 1986-87. The trend in increased numbers of invalidity cases received continued in to 1987-88.
The Authority states that, if this continues for the next year, it will have very real problems, with a lack of resources to deal with them.

Something which I am also particularly worried about is the growing number of members who have been discharged on invalidity grounds within one year of entering the defence forces whereas the condition that caused their retirement existed before their entry into the forces. This year, for the first time, that figure exceeded the number of other invalidity retirements.

What does this say for recruiting standards? I have been very concerned about those for some time. In fact, I have raised this matter in the past at Estimates committee hearings but officers have denied that there is a problem, although I believe that servicemen have been recruited into the Army with bands on their teeth, with flat feet and with asthma, all of which have been declared to the Services; yet they have been recruited. It is no wonder that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) is on the record as having told us on a number of occasions that she is having no trouble recruiting into the defence forces. Of course, she needs to recruit desperately in order to fill the gaps created by those who are leaving. I am concerned that here is the evidence as to what is happening. We are recruiting people who are not fit for the services.

Servicemen have to put 5.5 per cent of their income each fortnight into the scheme but get no return whatsoever by way of interest if they do not wait 20 years.

This scheme has been criticised roundly in the recent Cross report on wastage rates in the Defence Force. There has been some publicity about the matter, but the Government has chosen not to take any action. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It is important to indicate that these figures do not represent the total number of abortions. SPEECH.PARA: I do not suggest that that ought to be transposed to the rest of Australia, because of certain factors which I do not have time to go through now. But I think it is fair to add, conservatively, 25 per cent to the figure of 61,879, which gives a tragic figure of 80,000 deliberate abortions performed in Australia.

It is important to note these statistics, to reflect on them and to consider what action needs to be taken to ensure that this tragedy does not continue. Australia Health, the first biannual report of the Australian Institute of Health, talks about-for the first time in a public document-`easier access to abortion as a method of birth limitation'. We have reached an all time low as a civilised society if we deliberately take human life purely for convenience. That would be the case if, as suggested by that official report of the Australian Institute of Health, there were easier access to abortion as a means of birth limitation. I believe that it behoves all members of the Senate, all members of the Parliament, all thinking individuals, to consider the implications of these figures and to take action to end this tragedy.
