TALK.START.PARA: —As the Chair of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, which carried out most of the inquiry into the potential of the Kakadu National Park region, I would have liked to take the brief time available to me today to comment on the majority report which, I believe, has a range of recommendations which are appropriate to the significance of the Kakadu region to all Australians and, indeed, in the sense that a large section of it is now a World Heritage area, its significance to the world. But, as the only Government senator of the two members who served on both committees, I believe that I have a responsibility to set the record straight by examining some of the substance and recommendations of the dissenting report.

SPEECH.PARA: Since two of the three Opposition members of the present Committee have taken little part in the inquiry or the subsequent discussion of the report-they were late arrivals to it-I believe Senator Crichton-Browne to be the chief author of that dissent. What puzzles me is that the content of the dissent and even its rhetoric have very strong echoes of the material presented to us during the inquiry by the mining lobby, in particular by the representatives of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines. Yet the signatories to the dissent have attacked environmentalists and conservationists who they claim have a vested interest in the future of Kakadu. Sure, some of us may be said to have a vested interest in maintaining a unique part of our heritage for future generations, but surely the vested interests of the mining industry, of a more short term and self-interested nature, must also be acknowledged.

Similarly, at several points in the dissenting report there are references to the alleged lack of `intellectual rigour' and/or integrity or accusations of philosophical prejudice on the part of those inside or outside the Committee whose views differ from those of Senators Crichton-Browne, Panizza and McGauran. These claims, however, are nowhere supported with intellectual rigour. Many of their arguments are based on their perceptions of the views of environmentalists and/or Government members of the Committee, rather than on the opinions themselves as expressed in the submissions or in the majority report. For example, there is an assumption that, because we are concerned with the potential damage from mining, we do not recognise potential damage from tourism. An example of this occurs in their dissent relating to visitors' fees, where it is claimed that the majority believes that present park facilities are adequate, when our recommendation clearly states:
The fees levied should be related to the provision, improvement and maintenance of services and facilities in the park.

The dissenters, who claim lack of integrity on the part of those opposed to them, had no qualms about attempting to discredit the appointment of Ms Lyn Allen to the Coordinating Committee for the Alligator Rivers Region. The dissenting report states:
We can think of no justification for having Ms L. Allen as a member other than for blatant Party politicking.

The same Ms Allen has a bachelor of science degree in chemistry and zoology, an honours degree in environmental studies and three years experience in environmental monitoring-working for the mining industry, incidentally-prior to becoming Coordinator of the Northern Territory Environmental Centre. I would have thought this was just the sort of technical competence that the dissenters say is needed on that Committee.

The dissenting report claims that a large area of land has been `indiscriminately' set aside for inclusion in the World Heritage listing. Clearly, the writer or writers did not follow the lengthy and thorough preparation which occurred in applying for listing or even the heated debate in this chamber at the time. I am sure that Senator Crichton-Browne, as I do, remembers that clearly. It is the international body, however, that made the decision on the basis of the evidence put to it. So, is the minority claiming that the international body has acted indiscriminately?

In the debate of the week before last, several senators referred to the size of Kakadu National Park. Again this was a recurrent theme in the submissions of the mining companies. The size of the park, whether in terms of square kilometres or relative to areas in other parts of Australia, is really irrelevant. What is relevant is the integrity of the World Heritage wetlands in stages 1 and 2 of the park. They are dependent on rivers flowing from and through stage 3. The purity, both chemically and in terms of sedimentation, of the river system-in particular the South Alligator River, which flows through the conservation zone at the foot of Coronation Hill and close to the other areas where exploration is taking place-is vital to the abundant and unique life of the wetlands. I cannot agree with the claim by the dissenters that Australia's reputation did not suffer by the excision of the uranium mining zones from the park. I remind the Senate that those excisions were made under the previous Fraser coalition Government.

I referred earlier to the heavy influence the mining lobby's views seem to have had on the dissenting report. An 11-page addition to one paragraph in chapter 3 is a very lengthy and selective history of the debate about mining and exploration in the area. Significantly, it fails to include any mention of the action of one well known mining company in illegally attempting to continue exploration in stage 2 in the leadup to the World heritage hearing. One sentence from this section of the report is worth particular comment. In referring to mining claims it states:
Ultimately a World heritage listing for an Australian park was paramount to . . . property ownership within the Park.

Few Australians with any knowledge of or feeling for national parks would accept the philosophical position which is implied here-that private ownership is appropriate in a national park. That leaves aside the hypocrisy of wishing also to deny the rights of the traditional Aboriginal owners.
Elsewhere the dissenting report, on the subject of royalty payments, states:
We are opposed to the principle of providing a retrospective benefit to Aboriginal land claimants in a land title in which they had no proprietary interest . . .

Yet the mining companies are supposed to have a proprietary interest. How much longer after the Aborigines did they arrive? Prior ownership is clearly determined by those senators on the basis of the colour of the claimants' skin. Is this the intellectual rigour that they claim to have and that they claim we do not have?

I spoke the week before last about the use of in camera evidence in the dissenting report. I will only add now that that evidence was selectively quoted to omit evidence in conflict with the minority's view on Jawoyn beliefs about the significance of Coronation Hill. My view, formed not only from that evidence but also from other discussion with Jawoyn leaders is that some, perhaps all, of the senior custodians believe genuinely and strongly that Coronation Hill is a significant site and that mining should not take place there or elsewhere in what is known as the `sickness country'. This was put strongly to the previous committee at an informal meeting on Coronation Hill on 21 May 1986. Senator Crichton-Browne was not present on that occasion. The belief was expressed with obvious emotion to us then and has been reiterated by the recent Jawoyn delegation to Canberra which spoke with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other Ministers, including, I believe, Senator Richardson, who was also present as a Committee member at that first meeting. It is my firm conviction that that belief is genuinely held and that it should be for the Jawoyn themselves to decide, without pressure, what development can occur on their traditional land. There are many other parts of the dissenting report which are open to criticism as ignoring the balance of evidence or as misperceptions, to put it kindly, about the recommendations in the majority report. I hope to have time to mention a few. The majority recommendation at paragraph 95 reads:
The Committee recommends that the resources made available for the study of the environmental impact of the Ranger Uranium Mine should, as a minimum, be maintained at current levels.
The dissenting report then adds these words:
Subject to the release of the information not being of a commercial detriment to Ranger Mines.

The addition seems to be quite unconnected to our recommendation, which makes no mention of any release of information. Again, I wonder where that idea came from. The dissenting report's recommendation on mining in the conservation zone is so loosely worded as to be valueless. It says that approval should not be given to mining if `unacceptable damage' would result. Unacceptable to whom? It then goes on to say that infrastructure should be planned so as to `facilitate, as far as practicable, the later use of the area as a national park'. What does `as far as practicable' mean? It certainly gives me no comfort. I mention one last gem. In a paragraph supporting the miners' claim about effective rehabilitation, the minority report says that Senator Crichton-Browne considered rehabilitated areas in the Myall Lakes region, shown to us as a model, as `more attractive and more substantial than the original vegetation'. He obviously did not notice the increased weed infestation, among other things. If Senator Crichton-Browne was correct, perhaps we should mine or bulldoze all national parks and plant gardens there later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are addressing comments with regard to the Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on the Potential of the Kakadu National Park Region. I suggest that, within that broad title, the word `potential' is probably the key one. While Senator Zakharov has just criticised the dissenting part of the report for what she termed a lack of intellectual integrity, I would highlight the fact that, after three years in preparation, the majority report has now put forward some 40 recommendations, obviously very strongly under the influence of Senator Zakharov, who, I understand, is a psychologist and not necessarily someone with mining or major environmental issues at heart. The remarkable fact is that none of the recommendations directly address the terms of reference that were given to the Committee. The report reaches no conclusion on the nature of the resources available for exploitation or on the impact of the utilisation of these resources. I think it is worth referring to the particular terms of reference. They were:

SPEECH.PARA: The potential of the Kakadu National Park region with particular reference to:
(a) the nature of the resources available for exploitation; and
(b) the impact of utilisation of these resources, particularly on mining and tourism.

In other words, the majority report shirks and evades its prime responsibility. The terms of reference required the Committee to inquire into the nature of the resources available for exploitation in the Kakadu National Park. And during the three-year period of this inquiry-of which Senator Zakharov was Chairman for the period up to the last Federal election-the Federal Government, of which Senator Zakharov is a member, has put in place policies which, by prohibiting any mining exploration within stages 1 and 2 and two-thirds of stage 3 of the park, make it impossible to discover the true value of the mineral wealth of the region. All the countries with developed economies fully exploit their mineral resources if they are competitive. It is not a sign of a developed economy to ignore rich mineral resources. It is difficult to think of any country-east, west, north or south; rich or poor-which would sit on mineral resources of the magnitude that exists in the Kakadu region and do so little to exploit them-any country, that is, except Australia.

The majority report and the dissenting report adopt markedly different stances on the national economic imperatives of exploiting the resources of the region, on the environmental impact of exploitation and on the position of Aboriginals. The majority report makes a series of recommendations which seem intended to put obstacles in the way of mining companies without making firm recommendations for or against mining. However, in the dissenting report, my colleagues Senator Crichton-Browne, Senator McGauran and Senator Panizza conclude that Australia cannot afford to neglect these resources for economic reasons; that the environmental impact would be negligible; and that the Aboriginals would benefit greatly. Kakadu has the land area of a moderately sized country. It is one of the five most mineralised regions in the world. The Ranger mine has proven that a major mine can operate in the area with negligible environmental impact. The Koongarra mine alone would generate some $256m of revenue for Aboriginal interests. Common sense surely dictates that both the national interest and the Aboriginal interests would be best served by a policy of multiple land use which allows mining to proceed subject to rational environmental controls.

Additionally, I believe the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) should hand over management of this park to the Northern Territory Government. This would place the Northern Territory on a similar footing to that of the States. The ANPWS management of the parks is an obstacle to tourist development. Tourist infrastructure is inadequate for even current park visitors, and this is frustrating for the tourist industry and possibly a hazard to the environment in the long term. The majority report recommends that a board of management be established with a majority of Aboriginal traditional land owners. This is simply ludicrous, particularly when one takes into account the numbers of people and the resources that are available to them in the particular area.

It is difficult to reconcile the emphasis given in the majority report to the consideration of Aboriginal interest with the Committee's terms of reference. I remind the Senate-and the report acknowledges this-that there are only 277 Aborigines living in the Kakadu region of 19,804 square kilometres. Ninety-three per cent of stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park is not Aboriginal land, and no claim has been granted on stage 3. Yet the majority report recommends that a board with a majority of traditional owners be created to manage Kakadu National Park. The majority report seeks to impose stringent Aboriginal employment conditions on mining company projects within the region. However, the dissenting report remarks that it is virtually impossible to locate in the park Aborigines who are available and prepared to work. Seventy-five per cent of the people employed by the Gagudju Association are white, and the two hotels owned by that Association employ 100 staff, of whom only five are Aborigines.

The dissenting report finds evidence of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs on Aboriginal attitudes to mining factually incorrect. Revenue which would flow to Aboriginal interests from the Koongarra mine alone, as I said earlier, is established at some $256m. The majority report calls for royalty payments to Aboriginal groups who have lodged land claims-in effect, retrospective benefits. The dissenting report states that this would place mining companies in an intolerable situation and the prospects of financial blackmail are enormous. I would certainly commend the commonsense attitude that has been taken by Senators Crichton-Browne, McGauran and Panizza. Their report very adequately reflects the views that I think are generally and widely held and with which most of the community would be very comfortable. Let me give some quotes from the dissenting report which I believe accurately reflect its particular emphasis. On page 263 it is stated:

. . . if it could be shown that, with proper management, resource development would produce wealth for Australia with little or no damage to the environment, then a compelling argument is to be had for such exploitation. The current Government policy excludes such determinations in all but the Conservation Zone.
A further quote from page 263 reads:

It is quite irresponsible and improper for any Government to attempt to develop policy on mining, tourism or any other land use without having assembled the relevant and imperative information. However, what can be asked is whether Australia can afford to forgo many billions of dollars of natural wealth because that wealth is located in an area around which a national park has been declared.
I quote from page 264:

We recommend that permission be given for the Jabiluka and Koongarra mines to go into production. To put aside a recommendation would be to fail in many respects to address the central questions which the Senate directed to the Standing Committee on National Resources and, subsequently, the Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee to consider and report upon . . .
Page 270 reads:
We recommend the adoption of a policy of balanced and sensitive multiple land use within Kakadu National Park.
It is the dissenting report that is being considered by the Senate, relating to the potential of Kakadu National Park, which properly reflects common sense and a blueprint for governments to adopt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might respond first to the suggestion that has been put by Senator Zakharov, in a very uncharitable and inaccurate way, that our minority report reflected the subjective and vested views of the mining industries. Let me say that that is, without doubt, totally untrue, and Senator Zakharov in her heart would know it. I am disappointed that she has said other than that which she knows to be the truth. The minority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts was written on the basis of the quality of the evidence provided, the integrity of that evidence, and its capacity to be subject to probing and testing on its presentation.

SPEECH.PARA: The quality of the evidence which was provided by some of the anti-mining groups, some of the anti-uranium groups, some of those who maintain a level of prejudice, bigotry, bias and distortion which even I had never seen before, reflects upon them and is a statement about them. If I could not find some merit in their argument, it was not because I was biased, but because of the distortion of the evidence. I am sure that Senator Zakharov knows that. I come to the central question which caused this report to be put forward. The terms of reference were compiled as a result of a suggestion put by me to Senator Graham Richardson, now the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, who said he thought the proposal for the inquiry had a great deal of virtue and merit and that he would support it. There was no point in my putting it to the Committee-as Senator Zakharov would know-without at least the support of some Government members, because the terms of reference would have failed to be adopted from the outset.

However, one ought to look at the quality of the recommendations of the majority report. I say to the Senate, with respect, that they reek of prejudice, are fraught with distortion and fail on the central point of honesty. The question to be put at the beginning of the day by all of us was whether mining ought to take place in Kakadu National Park. Senator Zakharov knew that, I knew it, and every member of the Committee knew it. At the end of the day, the majority report failed to address that question. Why did it do so? It was because Senator Zakharov had already publicly committed herself to opposing mining in Kakadu National Park. Senator Zakharov was already totally opposed to uranium mining anywhere in Australia.

On the other hand, Senator Bob Collins, an Australian Labor Party senator for the Northern Territory, has publicly committed himself to mining in Kakadu National Park. Senator Collins was the spearhead of the Koongarra group of Aboriginal people who came down to Hobart and lobbied outside the Australian Labor Party National Conference, calling upon that Conference to agree to mining at Koongarra. Senator Collins knows that mining at Koongarra is worth $650m to the Aboriginal community alone. But in order not to have a conflict in the Committee and so as not to divide the Australian Labor Party members of that Committee, they did what one would expect in this day and age: they pragmatically judged it was wiser to make no recommendation. Therefore, nobody was offended, nobody had to dissent and nobody had to disagree. In that way, Senator Zakharov, Senator Collins, Senator Black and the Australian Democrats could agree to a report, which ended up being the majority report. But they made no real report; they made no recommendation; they made no findings. I believe that is a cheap way of writing reports. It reflects pretty unfairly on the normal integrity of standing committee reports put down in this Parliament.

Mr Acting Deputy President, let me remind you that when the time came to make recommendations in respect of whether there ought to be tourism in the park, fishing in the park or hunting in the park; whether a township ought to be built in the park-and the effects of Jabiru township on the park-or whether buffalo ought to be allowed in the park, the majority report had no difficulty in reaching a conclusion. That was because those members were of one accord. It was only when they had to swallow the fundamental question of uranium mining that they choked and threw up a report of the quality and nature of this one. That is what happened at the end of the day. Notwithstanding their judgment as to what sort of report it ought to be and what sort of a park we ought to have-it seemed to me that it almost had to remain in its pristine state before they would be satisfied-notwithstanding the fact that they said there should be no commercial fishing or hunting, or hunting as a recreational sport, that no exotic diseases or animals should be introduced; one is not allowed, if one lives in Jabiru, to own two cats; at the end of the day, the majority report recommended that wild buffalo be left in the park.

The truth is that the Australian ecology and environment are not compatible with hard-hoofed animals. Senator Zakharov ought to know that. Not only are they being encouraged to remain in the park at a time when an eradication program is going on to remove them because of the damage that they cause, but also Senator Zakharov is suggesting that their presence ought to be enshrined in law. Why? Because the Aboriginal community is now used to them. Senator Zakharov describes them as part of the Aboriginals' `natural, staple diet'. I have to tell Senator Zakharov that that does not mean that one should build a Hungry Jack's there just because the inhabitants have got used to such food. The truth is that Senator Zakharov has totally trampled on every single principle she has had so far so as to leave buffaloes there. The majority report has no integrity.

Let me go to the heart of the question of in camera evidence. This is the second time that Senator Zakharov has raised the matter. This is not a reflection on Senator Zakharov; I do not wish to be pulled up under the Standing Orders. It is my view that there are those who had a vested interest to ensure that that evidence never be given public airing because it did not agree with, and was totally incompatible with, the majority report. At Barunga, when the Aboriginal community was given a chance to give evidence, it said almost without exception that it not only wanted uranium mining in Kakadu National Park, but also invited and embraced it.

As for Coronation Hill, it was news to members of the community that that site was of some sacred significance or of some spiritual interest to them. It was only after they had been told by the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority of the Northern Territory that this was a sacred site that the revelation struck them; they learned for the first time that there was something there of significance to them. At the end of the day, the decision was not made by them; it was made by a bunch of white people in the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority in Darwin, who had their own agenda. That agenda meant no mining for uranium in Kakadu National Park; it had nothing to do with the interests of the Aboriginal community. Those people have been used and abused, and they will be put aside in due course when this group goes on to some new and better agenda to give us a country that it believes in, not one which represents the views of the vast majority of Australian people.

The golden thread that ran through this report, as best I can identify one, was that so much was not known about uranium mining and its effect on the park. Having come across no evidence that could show that there had been any damage to the park in the past as a result of uranium mining, a mist and a cloud of mystique and the unknown had to be thrown up, as no evidence of previous effects and previous damage could be referred to. It ought not to be forgotten that so far 1,000 reports have been written about the effect of uranium mining in Kakadu National Park, and 150 alone in respect of the tailings dam in the Ranger uranium mine area. There was no intellectually compelling technical evidence given to the Committee which suggested for a moment that uranium mining had had any significant detrimental effect upon the ecology, the environment or the general area of Kakadu National Park. Because that evidence was there, we suddenly had to engage in the mystique and say that it is what we do not know that counts, not what we do know.

I found the majority report disappointing because it did not seek to address the fundamental questions which it was required to. For instance, it did not address the question of why we can have mining at Ranger, yet we cannot have it at Koongarra. The way the problem was solved by the Australian Labor Party was to draw the lines around the areas that were economically viable and then it could argue that it had ensured the integrity of the park. Of course that was untrue and quite intellectually dishonest. So I recommend that all those who want spiritual enlightenment, who want to learn something and who have an unbiased and objective view as to the effect of the Kakadu National Park should read the minority report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. I did not have a pen to hand when Senator Crichton-Browne spoke, so I do not have his exact words before me. But Senator Crichton-Browne certainly implied that I was not saying what I believed in my heart. I consider that is a gross imputation to make against my character. I do not normally say what I do not believe. He also said-this is not in breach of Standing Orders, as I understand it, because he was not referring to a particular person but to a group of people-that the majority was dishonest. I take strong exception to both of those remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a question with regard to ex gratia payments, which come, as far as I am aware, under the purview of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), as is the one who usually either approves or, more generally, disapproves them. This case is a matter that I have referred to before in this place. It involves a particularly unsavoury case of the sexual harassment of a female officer in the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). She joined the Air Force in 1980. She suffered a considerable amount of sexual harassment in 1982. She was finally forced out of the Air Force and into private life. I say at this point that the two officers concerned and some other people who had been involved in the harassment were eventually dismissed or otherwise disciplined for their actions. So there was definitely an acknowledgment by the Air Force that the woman had been subjected to the treatment she claimed. There is no question of somebody simply making an issue that is nebulous. It was one that was categorised. She was proven to be correct and the people concerned were disciplined. In any event, she left the Air Force and went into private life.

SPEECH.PARA: The harassment continued after she left the Air Force, after she moved away from that State to another State. I might add here that her marriage breakdown is a consequence not only of the sexual harassment but also of the allegations by those who were accused of it that she was a lesbian. She was put under enormous physical and emotional stress. On top of all that, having moved to another State, she discovered that the harassment was continuing. She lost, for example, a work contract when the contractor who was to employ her was informed by a couple of RAAF personnel that she was a homosexual.

I do not think this sort of thing should be tolerated anywhere at all, but it certainly should not be tolerated in government employment of this sort without being challenged. There was a strong recommendation for an ex gratia payment for the woman concerned from both the Commonwealth Ombudsman and from the Defence Force Ombudsman. There was no question at all that she had been treated particularly badly and harassed out of her chosen field of employment. The recommendation for an ex gratia payment was turned down by the Minister for Finance because he alleged that the harassment took place before the Sex Discrimination Act, which makes it an offence for this sort of harassment to continue-indeed, to take place at all-came into force. I dispute the Minister's rationale because that harassment has continued since she left the Air Force, and it has been continued by RAAF personnel. That alone should make the Minister think again on this issue.

I raised the matter during the Comcare debate in June this year. The Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus), who I think was on duty in the chamber at the time, asked for more information. I passed on the details to his private secretary. Earlier this month I rang Senator Bolkus's office. His officers said that the best way to deal with it in their opinion was for me to have a meeting with the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mrs Kelly, whose area of operation deals with personnel, so that we between us could decide on the best approach to make to the Minister for Finance. Presumably Senator Bolkus and/or his office thought that both Ros Kelly and I bearding Peter Walsh in his den was likely to have more impact than would one of us on our own. In any event, it is not always possible for two people as busy as we are to meet with another Minister to get something like this fixed up.

There is a genuine case here for an ex gratia payment. The harassment took place when the woman concerned was in the Air Force. It continued after she left the Air Force and after the passage of the Sex Discrimination Act. That, in its own right, means that the Minister is not justified in denying an ex gratia compensatory payment to this woman simply because he believes that the original harassment took place prior to the passage of the Act and that it is that harassment and only that harassment for which she is entitled to claim an ex gratia payment. I do not believe this is the case. I believe that the recommendations from both the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the Defence Force Ombudsman need to be taken into account. I ask the Minister, who is now in the chamber, to reconsider his decision not to recommend that ex gratia payment, despite the high level of support for it, and to reconsider on the point that since the harassment has been continued-and it has been continued by defence personnel-this woman deserves what little monetary compensation she can get from the Government as a consequence of being forced out of her chosen field of employment and in at least one instance denied access to another job as a continuation of the harassment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is the appropriate occasion to raise a matter concerning the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB). It was established in April of 1976 with a number of, I would have thought, quite important functions. It was set up to examine proposals by foreign interests for investment in Australia and to make recommendations to the Government on those proposals. It was also required to advise the Government on foreign investment matters generally. That is a fairly vital element of investment in this country. It is certainly raising concerns in the community generally. Just how much of the farm and indeed the cities Australia is selling to foreign investors is something we do not know. Understandably, this is worrying a lot of people. We have no idea what parts of Australia are being bought up, what quantities, at what price or by whom. Part of the problem obviously is that Australia does not have a foreign ownership register. There is no way anybody in this country has of knowing who is buying what, what price they are paying for it, whether they are resident here and from which countries they come.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty with the FIRB is that it has an advisory function only. Responsibility for the administration of the Government's foreign investment policy and for making decisions on those proposals lies entirely with the Treasurer. It seems to me that the current Treasurer (Mr Keating) should be making more effort to take into account not only the feeling so Australians who are seeing large tracts of Australian land and property bought up by residents of other countries; he should also be concerned about what this is doing to the long term financial credibility of this country.

Since the Board was established in April of 1976 only one case has been prosecuted under the Foreign Takeovers Act, and I understand that that case was unsuccessful. Not only does it appear that the Government is not one jot concerned about who is buying up parts of Australia but also it is not apparently even concerned they are doing it appropriately and in accordance with whatever guidelines there may be in existence. Because if it has prosecuted only once in the last 12 years it obviously has not been keeping a close eye on what has been purchased by people from other countries. Even in that case, since it was unsuccessful, it would appear that there are loopholes one could drive the proverbial truck through. The penalties that exist for breach of guidelines and the law are simply not being applied to anyone.

That means that under the previous Fraser Government and under the current Hawke Government the Foreign Investment Review Board is nothing more than a piece of window-dressing to give gullible Australians the feeling that we are not selling off the farm when the reality of the situation is that the Hawke Government has downgraded the Foreign Investment Review Board from a division to a branch to begin with and then reduced its staff from 40 to fewer than 20. What makes that worse is that some of the 20 are part time temporaries and the FIRB is unable to fill some positions because of staff ceilings. All of this is happening at a time of dramatic increase in the number and value of foreign investment proposals. One could perhaps understand the staff being more than halved if proposals were dropping, if there were fewer people interested in buying up real estate or businesses in Australia, but that is not the case.

The Treasurer announced recently that the Foreign Investment Review Board is getting something like 400 inquiries per week about foreign purchases of urban real estate. In 1986-87-those are the latest figures that we have available-the Foreign Investment Review Board considered 1,352 proposals for investment in Australia. It did that with fewer than two dozen people. Of those 1,352 proposals, 1,347 were approved. A mere five proposals were rejected. That is a rejection rate of 0.4 per cent or thereabouts. Either all 1,347 proposals were crystal clear, absolutely above board, or the FIRB is simply too understaffed to be looking into the proposals adequately. I find it quite extraordinary and most unlikely that less than half a per cent of proposals would be rejected. If the FIRB is under-resourced and it is approving 99.6 per cent of all investment proposals, and the Treasurer refuses to prosecute those who infringe the Foreign Takeovers Act, it is clear that the Foreign Investment Review Board is being undermined because the Government lacks the political will to control and reduce the level of foreign investment.

I acknowledge at this point that the Government is moving in the area of the developed residential market so that we cannot have the New Zealanders, the Japanese, the Saudi Arabians or anybody else moving in here and, for investment purposes, buying up a lot of Australian residential property and putting the price of ordinary home ownership outside the means of many Australian families. We will certainly be supporting that legislation. It is overdue. But, by the same token, the Government needs to pay far more attention to other foreign investment in this country. What is more, the Australian people are entitled to know not only what is being bought and how much is being paid for it, so that they have some slight chance of working out what it is doing to the economy of this country, but also who is doing it. Australian corporations are allowed to increase our foreign indebtedness and they get a tax deduction into the bargain. That is bad enough. But when the FIRB is also being prevented from controlling the increasing level of foreign investment here, then we have a game of double jeopardy being played. It is the Australian people and the economy of this nation that are at risk.

Foreign investment certainly gives Australia the foreign currency to pay the interest bill accumulated by the local borrowers, but it is absurd that we have put ourselves into that position in the first place. What we have essentially done to ourselves is make Australia a sort of hotbed of international junkies, selling our businesses and, up until the time this legislation is passed, selling our homes, for heaven's sake, to foreign investors so that we can get the foreign currency we need to pay the interest on our overseas debts run up by local companies and corporations with the enthusiastic encouragement, it seems, of a Government which continues to offer tax concessions to people who put themselves in that position.

Even a quick look at the Foreign Investment Review Board's report of 1986-87 gives us some idea of the magnitude of the foreign investment that we are talking about. On page 4, under the heading `Summary of Proposals', we find this statement:
Total expected investment associated with foreign investment proposals approved by the Government in 1986-87 was $18.5 billion . . .

That is, $18.5 billion of foreign investment was approved by the Government. That is nearly double the 1985-86 expected level of $9.8 billion. This is the second successive year of massive growth in the level of foreign investment. That investment occurred, the report tells us, across most sectors, the notable exceptions being resources processing, finance and insurance, for which I suppose we should be grateful.

Of the $18.5 billion expected investment in the last financial year, 89 per cent was attributed to takeovers and acquisitions and the remainder to new businesses. About 70 per cent of the total expected new business activity, that is, about $1.9 billion worth, was concentrated in the services sector, much of it in tourism development. In recent times we have seen the Japanese, in particular, moving into the services and tourism area. They are building hotels on the Gold Coast for Japanese tourists. They are buying golf courses in Sydney to be used by Japanese tourists. They are running tourist shops, presumably to be patronised by Japanese tourists. That means that Australia is missing out on a lot of money because the profits will be going back to Japan. Most of the expected expenditures were in real estate. In 1986-87 $5.2 billion worth of Australian real estate was sold to foreigners, $5.6 billion in services, $3.9 billion in manufacturing and $2.3 billion in mining.

It is denying the Australian public information to which they are entitled if we give them no information at all about who the buyers are and what they bought with the incredible amounts of money they have been spending. It is essential that, at the very least, we have a register of foreign ownership in this country so that we know who is buying what, even if the Government is not prepared to stop them buying it. It would be a whole lot better if the Government gave some teeth to the Foreign Investment Review Board so that it was not expected, with a staff of under 20, to deal with over 1,300 inquiries. It would be even better if the Government placed the same sorts of restrictions on foreign ownership in Australia that most other countries place on foreign ownership in their countries. Australians cannot waltz into Hong Kong, Japan, or anywhere else much, and buy up the sorts of services, real estate and businesses that we are calmly selling off virtually to anybody who walks in here with the money to pay for them. I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), the Treasurer and the Government as a whole seriously to reconsider the Government's whole policy on foreign investment before we wake up one morning and find that we have sold ourselves to a conglomerate made up of the Japanese and the Saudi Arabians.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to raise one or two points concerning Estimates Committee C which arose during the recent Estimates examinations. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) will recall that recently the Committee had before it the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher. He will recall, I think, the question which Opposition senators raised with regard to the raid on Citibank Ltd and the audit that followed thereafter. The question raised during the course of that debate was whether, through the action of the auditors conducting their raid on Citibank Ltd in Melbourne and the action of the regional director of the Australian Taxation Office in Melbourne in releasing a press release coincidentally with that raid, there could possibly have been an offence under section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Honourable senators know that that section of the Act is very relevant because it protects the secrecy of the affairs of taxpayers as they are handled by the Commissioner of Taxation. The point we raised was simply this: because the Deputy Commissioner in Victoria issued a press release-albeit that no names were referred to, the activities undertaken by the Tax Office certainly were mentioned-and almost simultaneously the raid on City Bank Ltd became public knowledge, as the media had been tipped off, the two events were, of course, very clearly identified in the public mind. When that kind of action occurs there could possibly be a breach of the secrecy provisions by the Commissioner of Taxation. He might argue, on a technicality, that he did not, by issuing a press release, identify the name of a taxpayer. He might very well claim that. I think that argument would fall to the ground on the basis that it would be so easy to relate the raid on City Bank Ltd to the issue of a press release. There is a nice little loophole for the Commissioner of Taxation to exploit and identify taxpayers, thereby breaching the secrecy provisions.

I want to raise that point again today. I want to bring to the attention of the Senate some further remarks by the Commissioner of Taxation in a speech that he made to the Police Club in Adelaide last Monday. In that speech the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, said that he was examining a scheme whereby he would be able to list, presumably by category of taxable income, not so much the names but certainly the size of various companies operating in Australia. He would then identify, presumably in aggregate, the income of those companies and also the amount of tax that each of them would be paying.

We all know how zealous Mr Boucher is about the taxation law. I want to bring to the attention of the Senate that if such a procedure were adopted it would be a relatively easy thing for ordinary people in the community, because of the sheer numbers that would be aggregated in such an exercise, to identify which companies were in fact included in that aggregation. This could very easily lead to the disclosure of information, again in breach of the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. That point has to be noted now before the Commissioner of Taxation goes too far down the track of trying to nail skins to the wall, hanging up taxpayers wherever he sees them. We have a developing situation and he may very well, by some loophole in the law, be observing the actual letter of the law but breaching the spirit of it. I think his statements in recent times have led us to the point of view that the spirit of the law has to be observed rather than the mere letter.

Therefore, Mr Chairman, when we have other opportunities to raise these matters, we ought to debate at greater length this developing practice on the part of the Commissioner of Taxation. Suffice to say, at this point of time we are put on notice that there is a question mark about that kind of behaviour on the part of the Taxation Office. This practice could very well lead to the identification of individual taxpayers, intentionally or otherwise, by the Commissioner of Taxation and could breach that fundamental principle of the taxation law that the taxpayers' affairs are secret between him and the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation.

It goes without saying that if that principle were consistently breached we would see the annihilation of the principle, accepted up to now, of the maintenance of the independence of a Commissioner of Taxation. The income tax administration has been founded, as we all know, on the principle of there being an independent Commissioner, separate from government, separate from the Department of the Treasury, so that he can conduct his business with taxpayers without that information being disclosed to the political government. That is the fundamental principle upon which we have conducted our affairs over a long period. It is fundamental to our system of British justice. The role of the Chairman is to ensure that correct procedures laid down by the Senate are followed. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: In order to ensure that there is no misunderstanding about these matters, I have directed the attached letter to all of the Chairmen of the Estimates Committees.
I ask that that letter of the President to the Chairmen of the Estimates Committees be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows:
PRESIDENT OF THE SENATE
PARLIAMENT HOUSE
CANBERRA
3 November 1988
Senator B. K. Childs
Chairman
Senate Estimates Committee A
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Bruce Childs,

The question of the proper role of Estimates Committee Chairmen in the hearings of Estimates Committees has been raised with me, and in response I believe it would be useful to set out briefly what I consider to be the proper respective roles of Chairmen, members, Ministers and officers in Estimates Committee hearings.

As I see it, the role of the Chairman is to ensure that the procedures laid down by the Senate are correctly followed. These procedures are provided by standing order 36ab, under which Estimates Committees are appointed, other standing orders of the Senate and the resolution of 15 February 1988 relating to witnesses in so far as it is applicable to Estimates Committees. The most important task of the Chairman is to ensure that questions put to Ministers and officers are relevant, that is, that they relate to the expenditure of the department or authority under examination.

The role of the members and other Senators attending the hearings is to seek information by putting questions to the Minister and officers. Questioning, of course, can be detailed, probing and forthright in seeking to reveal maladministration. Chairmen should not seek to prevent tough questioning as such, but should seek to ensure that questions are put and answered in an orderly way, for example, that there is no disruptive interrupting of questions and answers.

It is for the Minister in attendance to determine in the first instance whether any particular question will be answered and whether it will be answered by officers. If a Minister considers that the questioning of officers is placing an undue burden on them, it is open to the Minister to determine that questions will be taken on notice or to assume responsibility for answering the questions. It should not be the role of the Chairman to protect the Minister or officers from questioning, unless the questions are clearly not relevant, the procedures of the Senate are otherwise being violated, or there is disorder.

I do not wish to suggest that any Chairmen have not followed proper procedures or have not properly carried out their role, or that Chairmen would not be aware of these matters, but the question of the role of Chairmen having been raised with me, I considered it appropriate to set down these thoughts.
If you have any comments on the procedures of Estimates Committees I would be happy to receive them.
Yours sincerely,
(Kerry W. Sibraa)

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Walters has been describing relates to only one part of the Government's obstruction of its accountability, as an Executive, to Parliament. One of Parliament's essential foundations is that the Government-that is, the Executive-is accountable to the Parliament. One of the reasons why we are here debating the Appropriation Bills is the old, well-established Westminster principle which has been taken up in every parliament based on the Westminster model all around the world; that is, that the government will be able to appropriate money only with the approval of Parliament. For us in the Senate to do our work more effectively, many years ago we set up Estimates committees. The six senators who sit on an Estimates committee examine minutely, line by line, the Budget of the Executive Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In this instance we had before us one statutory authority, one instrument of the Executive Government; that is, the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). There is in the Bill that is before the Committee now an appropriation which relates to providing money for the ABS to carry out its work. There is a requirement in the Act governing the Australian Bureau of Statistics-that is, law established by Parliament-for accountability and due approval to be given by Parliament for a program of the ABS to be undertaken in certain circumstances. What we found in the examination of this Government's executive action was that the Government was wanting; that there is an illegality in a program which the Government is pursuing.

My colleague Senator Walters has just now been speaking about the conduct of the chairman of one of the Estimates committees; that is, the Government senator who, as is our tradition in this chamber, chairs the Estimates committee's inquiries. Instead of giving fair play to the quite rightful, dutiful questions asked by senators of the Executive Government, we saw in the conduct of the Chair a bias towards protecting the Government to which that senator has allegiance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Teague, you must not impute improper motives to the Chairman. You may criticise the conduct of the Chairman, but you may not impute improper motives.

—I do not impute improper motives to the Chair, but I am entirely critical, along with all my colleagues in the Liberal and National parties, of the conduct of the Chair of Estimates Committee C in this instance. I am saying that this is part of a fabric of the Executive Government in recent times not living up to its proper accountability to Parliament. It is the Cabinet that is ultimately accountable to this Parliament for whatever decision it makes. A Minister of the Government is accountable to this Parliament, and a Minister acting for a Minister in the Senate is accountable-and so are the officers of any department.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the examination of the ABS survey, let me come to the point of the decision that was made by the Labor Cabinet. Earlier this year the Hawke Labor Government decided to approve an ABS household expenditure survey. This survey, amounting to more than 200 questions, was to be put to thousands of Australian households to enquire into the exact expenditure of that household on all items in a particular period. It was an enormously burdensome survey. A person whose household received the knock on the door from the ABS surveyor would have to spend hours and days to meet the requirements of the survey, and every kind of personal fact would need to be disclosed in the survey. One would have to disclose everything about one's house loan; what the value of one's property was; how much of a loan one had; whether one had three loans; whether it was a first or a second mortgage; whether there were any unsecured loans. People would be asked about their health. One would be asked: `Of every member of your household, how many visits have been made to the doctor? For what purpose? With what outcome? Give your full health history. Do you have a first job, a second job, a third job? What hours do you work? What are you paid?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your tax return?

—Yes, `What is your tax return? What is your gross taxable income? What is your net taxable income? What did you claim as a tax deduction? What was your tax refund?' It then deals even with the minutiae of household expenditure on food. It asks, `How much for the spaghetti? How many dozen eggs did you buy? How many litres of milk? Did you get it at a cut price supermarket? Where do you buy things? What did you give to the children for pocket money?'. People are told to keep a diary over weeks on every item of expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I am very critical of the minutiae of this overly burdensome and intrusive survey, let me say that there are appropriate samplings and questionings by the Bureau of Statistics that we in the Opposition very much support. Of course we support the principle of the existence of the ABS, and we support the rightful conduct, particularly through voluntary surveys, of appropriate matters on which government and other bodies will, because of the collection of statistics, make economic and other decisions. But the point about this survey is that it is twice as intrusive and twice as burdening of the Australian public as anything we have seen before-and there have been several household expenditure surveys in the past, including two surveys approved by a Liberal-National Party Cabinet. These were tabled in the Parliament and were open to scrutiny-and they gained bipartisan support in both chambers of the Parliament. That is not the case with regard to this household expenditure survey. It is excessively burdensome, it is excessively intrusive, and it does not have bipartisan support in the Parliament. The Opposition regards the survey as illegal. We say that the ABS has gone beyond the line and that the Cabinet has gone beyond the line. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, as the person responsible for the ABS, has gone over the line.

In examining the line-by-line budget with regard to ABS spending, Opposition senators want to ask a range of questions. Five hours of questions were put by the Estimates Committee to officers of the ABS and to the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, who is in the chamber and who represents the Treasurer. Those five hours of questions led us to various conclusions. Let me refer to those conclusions before moving a motion with regard to that conclusion. The conclusion which we set out in a report attached to the Estimates Committee C report to the Senate is as follows:

It is our conclusion that the survey is not legal. This assessment is not only based on the inadequate information basis of the Attorney-General Department's ruling of August 11, but also on the advice of the Clerk of the Senate and the independent legal opinion of Professor Douglas Whalan.

Senator Walters, in her speech during the second reading debate on this Bill, outlined very meticulously why it is our conclusion that this survey is illegal. There are significant differences between this survey and earlier surveys, and the Act requires that if there are significant differences, for the survey to be legal the Government must see that the survey is tabled in the Parliament.

Accordingly, bearing in mind all that has already been recorded in the report from Estimates Committee C, in Senator Walters's speech during the second reading debate, and in what I have said by way of introduction, I now move, pursuant to the procedural motion moved by Senator Cook earlier this day:
That, having considered the report of Estimates Committee C:
(1) The Committee is of the opinion that the Government should not continue with the ABS Household Expenditure Survey conducted from July 1988 on the grounds that-
(a) the survey is significantly different from earlier HES surveys and, as such, to be legal should have been tabled in Parliament prior to the survey being conducted; and
(b) the survey is extraordinarily burdensome and intrusive towards those members of the Australian public selected by compulsion for inclusion in the survey.
(2) The Committee is of the opinion that the Government should not in the future proceed with any ABS survey unless-

(a) where the survey is significantly different from surveys conducted prior to July 1988, the proposed survey and the proposed terms of conduct of the survey are tabled in Parliament and the Parliamentary debate on the proposed survey is fully taken into account; and
(b) the proposed survey is not extraordinarily burdensome and intrusive towards those members of the Australian public selected for inclusion in the survey.

It is in the best interests not only of the Senate but also of the Australian Bureau of Statistics for this motion to be adopted here today. Unless there is, by the tabling of a proposed survey in Parliament and by the Government of the day taking due notice of the parliamentary debate on that tabled survey, a retention of bipartisan support for important programs of the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the ABS will fall into public disrepute and the public will not cooperate with an onerous, intrusive, burdensome survey.

It is essential for this Government, or for a government of which I am a member in the future, to ensure that, by the executive Government being accountable to Parliament and by giving lawful notice to Parliament of the terms of a survey, there is full confidence in the Parliament that this is an appropriate survey and one which we as the representatives of the people can rightly agree with; that it goes forth with full public knowledge that it is lawful and that it is appropriately required that a sample of Australian people comply with it.

This is not the case now. Opposition senators are saying to the Australian public that this ABS survey is not legal. Members of the public who do not cooperate with it are rightly calling the bluff of an ABS surveyor who may say, during the doorstop interview, that it is compulsory that the questions be answered by the householder. I believe that the Government should recognise its mistake. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, should recognise his mistake. The Estimates process should be congratulated for bringing to light the inadequacy in the way in which the ABS and this Government have performed in this matter. An amount of $1.3m was expended, according to the appropriations before us, in only the first quarter of the conduct of this illegal survey. We are here to ensure that the appropriation is lawful and appropriate to be approved. That is why I have moved the preceding motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue has arisen mainly because of a misunderstanding, or possibly a misinterpretation by some of the basis of the advice of the Attorney- General (Mr Lionel Bowen) given some time in July. A number of documents were peddled to the press but withheld from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, because to have made the same documents available to the ABS would have spoiled the story and reduced the chance of getting some publicity for those people who were peddling it. This applies in particular to Professor Whalan's advice of 19 September.

SPEECH.PARA: On 20 October, after the Estimates committee hearings had been completed, the ABS became aware of advice that had been provided to Senator Walters by the Clerk on 19 September, three weeks before those hearings began. The advice was in the form of a document by Professor Whalan entitled, `Comments on the Commonwealth Ombudsman's Letter of 15 September 1988 to Mr D. M. Cameron, M.P.'. It was apparent that Professor Whalan's advice, like that given earlier by the Department of the Senate, misrepresented the ABS position. Professor Whalan stated that it is:
. . . the 1974-75 and 1975-76 collections, which are now relied on . . .
That appears in paragraph 14. He further stated:
. . . the 1974-75 and 1975-76 Surveys being relied on by the ABS to legitimate the 1988 Survey.
One should interpolate the verb `are' before `being relied on'. That appears in paragraph 19. I quote again:
. . . the 1974-75 and 1975-76 Surveys (are) claimed as the basis for 1988.
It was presumably on the strength of that advice that Senator Walters stated on 11 October that:
. . . the Bureau has repeatedly said that its whole reliance is on the 1974-75 and 1975-76 surveys . . .

In fact the Bureau made no such statement. Professor Whalan's conclusions appear to have been based on a misinterpretation of the memo of 11 August from the Attorney-General's Department and on a failure to understand that the conclusions of that memo were reached on two alternative bases-one being the surveys in the 1970s and the other being the survey in 1984. To clarify that matter the Statistician asked the Attorney-General's Department on 27 October:

In considering whether the differences between the 1988-89 Survey and the previous surveys rendered it a `new proposal' is it the changes from 1984 or the cumulative changes since 1974-75 which are relevant?
The answer of the Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department, received on 2 November, was:
The 1988-89 Survey was not a `new proposal' if it was not significantly different from the 1984 Survey.
The Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department also said:
A single relevant predecessor-
and this is very important-
would suffice to prevent the 1988-89 Survey from being a `new proposal'.
In the opinion of the Secretary of the Department:

the 1984 proposal, and the subsequent conduct of the 1984 Survey pursuant to that proposal, can be relied on as denying novelty to the 1988-89 Survey if that latter Survey did not differ to any significant extent from the 1984 Survey.
The Secretary's opinion continued:
If there was no significant difference between the 1984 and 1988-89 Surveys, it is unnecessary to decide-
I emphasise the words `it is unnecessary to decide'-
whether the differences between the 1974-75 and 1988-89 Surveys would take the latter Survey beyond the scope of an ongoing program.

If the ABS had known at an earlier stage of Professor Whalan's misconception, that is, the misconception that the legitimacy of the 1988-89 survey was dependent on the surveys of the mid-1970s-that is, while the Estimates Committee was still sitting until after it had finished-the Bureau's statement at the beginning of the Estimates Committee C hearings could have made it clear that the Attorney-General's Department saw no need to decide about differences between 1974-75 and 1988-89, because the 1984 survey was sufficient precedent. The exploration of these differences, or alleged differences, which consumed much of the time of Estimates Committee C might then have been avoided. These differences were thought to be relevant to the legal position only because of incorrect statements about the ABS position, which were provided to an Opposition senator without the Bureau's knowledge.

Finally, I go back to where I started. Had all of these opinions, misconceptions, anonymous QC's opinions, QC's opinions and other opinions been provided to the ABS or made public at the time they were made available, instead of being peddled around to the press gallery to try to get publicity for the people doing the peddling, all of this could have been sorted out long ago. Likewise, had the ABS known before, instead of after, the Senate Estimates Committee C conducted its hearings, it could have been sorted out in Estimates Committee C. I think it would be a gross waste of the Committee's time and of taxpayer's money if we spent too much more time talking about this.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has put the best possible gloss on the Government's conduct by describing this as arising from a misunderstanding. SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge the careful conversation that the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Haines) has had with me. I wish to speak for just a few minutes more to ask why this would be only a misunderstanding if a number of the assessments had not been so clearly established. For example, I refer to Mr Giles's, the Assistant Statistician, Social Welfare Branch-that part of the ABS that looks to its relationship with the people of Australia, that looks to the social impact of any program the ABS is to conduct. His clear written advice to the chief Australian Statistician earlier this year, before any of the controversy, was in these terms:

The Household Expenditure Survey is the most burdensome household survey undertaken by the ABS and is also considered to be highly intrusive by some members of the community . . . I therefore seek your approval to table the 1988-89 Household Expenditure Survey.

Instead, members of Parliament rightly raised this matter, and it was raised before it came to the attention of the Attorney-General's Department, before it came to the attention of the Ombudsman and before it came for legal opinion via the Professor and head of the law department and the Australian National University and others, including the Clerk of the Senate. Because members of Parliament were in a position to challenge a matter which ought to have been tabled and been subject to parliamentary discussion, it was appropriate for them to ask officers of the chamber, in this case the Clerk of the Senate, for advice. When that advice was given and made public and subsequently Professor Whalan's legal opinion was given and also made public, the Australian Statistician then tried to intimidate the Clerk of the Senate. TALK.START.PARA: —This year is the first year that the Department of Defence has conformed to the direction of the Department of Finance to present its estimates in program management form. The Department was given a one-year deferment to comply with this direction, unlike most other Federal departments. Looking at the way the Department's estimates were presented, one would have to doubt the sincerity of the Department's attempt to comply with the directive of the Department of Finance. Program budgeting requires two basic conditions, firstly that the objectives for each section be set out and, secondly, that performance indicators be drawn up so that measurements can be made as to how the department is performing in pursuit of its objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Estimates hearings this year not one performance indicator was given by the Department of Defence. This, given the normal reluctance of the Department of Defence to give free and happy advice as to how things are going, makes the job very difficult. I know that Senator Ray would agree.

The Department hides to an enormous degree behind the need for secrecy. The reality is that there is very little secret material in the Department of Defence. The performance characteristics of most of the high technology weapons systems et cetera that we are involved with are well known to the Soviets and anyone else who takes an interest. There is an argument for secrecy to be maintained on a few issues but it relates only to a minority of activities of the Department. It certainly cannot be applied, as it has been by the Department, to the whole range of activities in which it is involved.

Some of the Department's objectives were defined reasonably well, though a number of them were defined in a rather woolly way. That applies to some of the objectives which were sheltered behind statements that they were objectives that were defined in the defence White Paper brought down last year. But it was the lack of any performance indicator which made judgment of the Department's performance very difficult, if not impossible.

I recognise that it is very hard in a defence department to make comparisons with normal commercial enterprises. One cannot run a defence force the way one would run an airline, a shipping line or a bank. One requires excess capacities to make up for search requirements for casualties and other demands that one cannot foresee. But we did not get one word from the Department that the system it was required to work to was inappropriate for it. My view is that it is inappropriate to impose the program management system dogmatically or doctrinally upon the Department. I instance the experience of countries such as Canada, the United States and some of the European countries which, 10 or 15 years ago, applied program management to their departments. They have now moved away from that system because they saw its shortcomings. I am not impressed with program management for this Department. I would rather see some other system. The Parliament needs to know what money is proposed to be spent and how effectively it has been spent. That is all that we require. We are not hung up as to what system is followed to deliver that information to the Parliament.

In many ways the Department's appearance at the recent Estimates hearings was one of the must unsatisfactory appearances by the Department for many a long year. We certainly got some significant information from the Department. We learned, for example, of the failure of the Government to consult with the RAAF before it brought in the disastrous pilot retention bonus scheme which has cost the taxpayer $11m for no benefit whatsoever. Those of us on the Committee know that it was something worked up in blind panic by the two Ministers to cope with the huge loss of pilots from the RAAF in the last three years. There has been some obfuscation of the point put out by the Ministry on this, such as that it had been done with the approval of the RAAF. We found out, on questioning, that the matter of a pilot retention bonus had been discussed with the Air Force two or three years back. Certainly, the proposal that was introduced this year was just dropped on it on the basis of `take it or leave it; we are going to do it'.

I was interested to know how many consultants were employed by the Department of Defence. I see in the papers that were distributed afterwards that the Department simply cannot tell us how many consultants were employed in the last 12 months. The answer from the Department reads:

The Department uses a wide range of services that might be described as consultants. These include services provided from, and controlled by, other departments (e.g., architects). The information needed to answer the Senator's question is not maintained centrally and it would take some time and necessitate the expenditure of significant resources to prepare.
That is an evasive answer, to put it in the kindest way. The Department knows very well how many consultants, such as Mr Cooksey, it did employ.

In one sense a lot of the information the Parliament is being given from estimates presented in this form is a collection of disjointed facts. It is also true that we get those disjointed facts because they are the questions that honourable senators on the Senate Estimates committees ask. Part of the problem flows from the system that is imposed on us under this program budgeting system.

The Department and the Ministry must take the Parliament into their confidence in relation to defence and defence expenditures. Defence is absolutely fundamental to any society. It is the first duty of a government. It is also a very expensive task. By putting a cloak of secrecy around the activities of the Department and the Defence Force, one does not create an informed, educated public. If one does not create an informed, educated public, one does not have public support for the high expenditures that are involved. The Parliament has to be taken into the confidence of the Department and the Ministry a great deal more. The Parliament has to have information to oversight what is going on, because in defence we are dealing with projects where the expenditure is not in the tens of millions of dollars but, in many cases, in the hundreds of millions of dollars or even thousands of millions of dollars.

The submarine program that we have embarked on was written at about $3.8 billion in prices of two years ago. When the program is completed it will cost the Australian taxpayer somewhere around $10 billion to $12 billion. It is a huge expenditure. It is the biggest contract we have written. One cannot get any information out of the Department of Defence as to how the submarine program is going at present. No-one will tell me at an Estimates Committee hearing. Yet we know very well from other sources that there are very considerable technical problems that are hazarding the success of the program. We know that there are very considerable cost overruns, from the information that is coming out from the people involved. Nothing is put on the record by the Department.

This is an intolerable situation. Not only is there this big amount of money involved in many defence contracts, but the importance of it to the basic security of Australia cannot be overestimated. Things we buy today in the way of major equipment dictate what sort of defence response we can make not in five or 10 years time but maybe in 20 or 25 years time. We close off a lot of options every time we sign a contract. We lose a great degree of flexibility. The Parliament has to have an oversight of how these contracts are going so that we can make some judgment as to whether things are on the rails.

That leads me to another point. The Estimates committees provide oversight to only a limited degree. When we get onto a big program, such as the submarine contract, it is very hard to run a high level, fully comprehensive audit as to what is happening. Certainly, audits are done by the Auditor-General with respect to making sure that no-one is thieving, stealing or doing dishonest things like that. But there is no independent body set up by the Parliament, which really is the client, to assess how the program is going, whether it is on time, whether it is on budget, what the technical problems are and, importantly, what the technical relevance of it is. The submarine program requirements were drawn up maybe six years back. By the time the first one is built, at least 10 years will have elapsed since pen was first put to paper. It may be that the technical relevance of some of the equipment, some of the weapons system, has changed enormously. We in the Parliament have no way of knowing how appropriate those things are.

I come back to the central point of the Estimates Committee, that is, to provide accurate information, particularly on programs of capital procurement. Yesterday I raised the matter of Project Parakeet and the way one of the officers of the Department misled the Parliament in that inconsistent advice was given in two consecutive Estimate Committee hearings-the Estimates Committee hearing in April this year and the one in October. What action does the Government propose to take with respect to that officer?

I am not interested in Westpac now. Their form begins ``I/we wish to transfer . . . to the following branch of Westpac'' and requires a signature.
