TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his responses to that first series of questions in relation to the defence service homes scheme. I would like to touch on another matter. I believe there is some degree of sympathy within the Department of Veterans' Affairs concerning the circumstances of merchant seamen in the Second World War. In fact, I think there is at the moment some deliberation about the need to revisit the Act under which their entitlements are at present administered. I am simply seeking some clarification as to whether there is an acknowledgment in the appropriations that perhaps the Department will see fit to be more generous in its considerations of those who served in the merchant navy.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, one has always known informally of the enormous contributions and sacrifices which were made by this arm of the service. It is no secret that for many years now merchant seamen have been dissatisfied with their entitlements in comparison with those who receive their entitlements under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. I have had some informal indications that these discrepancies are in fact under consideration and that that will possibly be addressed by a revision of the Act which affects merchant seamen veterans, or perhaps it may be that their entitlements will be absorbed under the Veterans' Entitlements Act itself. The point I am really making is that there is great dissatisfaction, and has been for several decades now, among those who served in the merchant marine service as to what their entitlements are in comparison with those of the remainder of the veterans community. The fact that the floor of every ocean on earth is littered with the remains of merchant ships, great and small, which were deliberately sunk as acts of war is a great but hidden testimony to the merchant navy's enormous service to our nation. It is perhaps a case of `out of sight, out of mind' that it has been necessary for their case to be documented so graphically and to be presented repeatedly to the Minister in an attempt to achieve some degree of equality.

I would like to place on record the fact that the Australian Democrats have made representations on quite a number of occasions on behalf of merchant seamen. I remind the Committee of the degree to which they see themselves discriminated against and the wide degree of entitlement discrepancy which exists between those who are entitled under the Veterans' Entitlements Act and those who are entitled under the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act.

The following facts concerning some of the conditions which Australian merchant seamen lived and operated under during the Second World War appear to be the basis upon which that resentment is based: merchant seamen's rate of pay was considerably less than that to which other servicemen were entitled at that time. They were not issued with uniforms. There were no regular qualified medical services available to them. No medical checkup was given to merchant seamen upon discharge from their ships. The bulk of Australian merchant seamen served on foreign allied ships. This was due to the small number of Australian vessels in service.

Australian merchant mariners come under the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act, and this Act differs greatly from the Repatriation Act, as I have said, in that the former Act places the onus on the claimants to prove their injury or disability. In many instances this injury or disability was war caused. Only a few thousand Australian merchant seamen served in the Second World War. They ask the question: why were they discriminated against by coming under a different Act? All Australian service personnel, they argue, should be provided for under the Repatriation Act. We believe that the Department of Veterans' Affairs is currently rethinking its attitude towards this discrimination due to the administration of entitlement under two separate Acts.

The servicemen argue that they were not welcomed home, as were members of the other Australian armed services. That is the sort of grievance which underlaid the resentment, until recently, of those who had served in Vietnam. They claim that they were not deprogrammed after the war. Many of them still live with the consequences of not having gone through-to use their expression-a `deprogramming'.

It is noted that Vietnamese, American and other allied ex-service personnel living in Australia are eligible for war service pensions and full repatriation benefits, but that the seamen are not. They see that as a clear act of discrimination against them. Statutes to remove discrimination of all types are being proclaimed throughout Australia; yet they, as merchant seamen of the Second World War, believe that, because they come under a separate repatriation Act, they are clearly being discriminated against for the reasons I have just mentioned.

They say that they were a fighting service, as most wartime merchant ships were armed and the defensively equipped merchant ships gunner in the British or Australian navies was seconded to merchant vessels for the purpose of training ships' crews in the proficient use of heavy and light armaments. They say that the services provided by the merchant navy in the conveyance of troops, fuels, ammunition and other war essentials contributed significantly to the allied forces' victory. Accordingly, they simply request that they be viewed as having made the same contribution as those who served in other branches of the service.

Merchant navy personnel served in the following theatres of war: Russian convoys, Pacific islands, Malta, Dunkirk, Sicily, Normandy, North Atlantic, Coral Sea, Middle East, New Guinea, Manila Bay and Tokyo. It is on these grounds, therefore, that there is a deep feeling of resentment among those who served in the merchant seamen services. It is as an expression of that resentment that I pose to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) the question: Is the Department of Veterans' Affairs anticipating-as we believe it may be-some variation or amendment to the Act within the next financial year whereby the objections of merchant seamen will be accommodated, and their entitlements varied and accommodated, within the appropriations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing in the current estimates to improve the benefits, as Senator McLean would well know. Senator McLean equated the return of merchant marines after the Second World War with the reception accorded to Vietnam veterans when they returned. Nevertheless, the underlying substance of Senator McLean's relaying of the matters put forward, particularly by the Merchant Navy War Service League, is before the Government and is being given proper deliberation in the priorities which are a necessary part of any government in making its Budget allocations.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will be aware that, after the report of the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee was handed down, the priorities appeared to be the injection of additional moneys into the repatriation hospital system. Certain new initiatives were put forward by that Committee. Those were established in the Budget and in the estimates before the Committee at the moment, but that is not to say that proper consideration is not being given to the claims of merchant mariners for, as they put it, equality of treatment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted tonight to raise a couple of matters in relation to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs that were the subject of debate in the hearings of Estimates Committee E. I thought that the handling by departmental officials and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) in the Estimates Committee hearing of these matters was very good. It was an example that could well be adopted by some other departments so far as the quality of the preparation of notes for Estimates committees was concerned. I thank them for that.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the matters which we raised in particular during the Estimates debate-and one on which, having now re-read the Hansard transcript of the debate, I think the Government had the better of the duel-was the question of whether the Department has been setting targets or quotas for various posts around the world over the last couple of years. There was a very interesting debate on that aspect. As I understand it, without going into all the details of the debate, the Department finally told us that targets were not set and that staffing at the various immigration posts, at our diplomatic offices around the world, was not pre-determined but was based very significantly on the number of applications and the demand coming out of each post. In other words, the staffing situation was demand driven rather than the reverse. Subsequently, in response to questions that we asked about this matter, some very interesting and useful figures came forth in terms of the staffing of posts with immigration officials, both locally engaged staff and with the Australian based staff, and a corresponding set of data as to the extent of the backlog existing in applications at the different posts. On the basis of the information and the data provided, there have been major staffing increases in the following posts so far as locally engaged staff are concerned: China, Chile, Fiji, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Mexico, the Philippines, Poland, Syria, Thailand and the USA. So far as Australian based staff are concerned, there has been an increase of two or more positions in the posts in Hong Kong, Malaysia and I think Mexico.

Those increases were accompanied by significant falls in the following posts in the locally engaged staff: West Germany, Italy, Spain, the United Kingdom and Yugoslavia. The falls of Australian based staff occurred mainly in West Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, the United Kingdom, the United States of America and Yugoslavia. So the conclusion in terms of staffing is that the main rises have occurred in Asian and South American countries and the main falls have occurred in European countries.

But when we look at the backlog of applications, it is interesting to note that the countries that have the main backlogs of applications include-this is not all inclusive-the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada and some of the European posts I mentioned before. In other words it would appear that, particularly so far as some of the European, North American and British posts are concerned, there have been falls in the staff, both locally engaged and Australian based, despite the fact that there have been significant backlogs of applications in those places.

I would like an explanation from the Minister if he is able to give it now-if he is not he can take it on notice again-as to the basis of determining the staff level at posts around the world, because I do not believe that the figures that have been given to us support the proposition that was made in the Estimates Committee hearing that the staffing at the posts is demand driven. I would appreciate an answer on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —These matters are not always as simple as they appear on paper. Delays and backlogs are caused for a whole variety of reasons. In some parts of the world delays occur through the propensity for forgeries. In others it depends on the nature of those applying. For instance, if people are applying in a country whose people have a propensity to apply under the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act there are also long delays for testing. I have maintained, and I continue to maintain, that the staffing of overseas posts is on the basis of demand and previous successful applications. It is not easy to allocate staff.

SPEECH.PARA: The inference that was made earlier, that we had targets almost in terms of quotas, is not true. It was basically circulated around for political reasons to protect another position. I think the inference of what Senator Short is asking is that there is some sort of conspiracy to deprive the WASPs of the world of their right amount of support staff. I take it no other way. I am simply saying that that is not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is a misinterpretation. What I am asking is this: Are you not in fact setting targets or quotas for various posts before the staffing levels are determined? The implication in the Estimates Committee was that it was done the other way around, and the data that has been supplied does not support that proposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the evidence at the Estimates Committee was that two different systems have been used, that one had been trialled and then almost reversed. We are now very much in a position to allocate staff according to what we think the demand will be. The field of immigration has always had backlogs, going back almost to the year dot. It is something that I think only technology and a rational points system will be able to assist, with quick processing. That is something I do not think any government has had in the last two decades. But I assure Senator Short that there is no intention within my Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs or at my ministerial direction to favour one region of the world over another; no intention whatsoever. I would not tolerate such a situation.

SPEECH.PARA: If the honourable senator wants to go into a detailed discussion about why there are two staff in one spot or three in another, I am not in a position to do so here in the Committee of the Whole. We might take that up in the Estimates Committee that considers the Supplementary Estimates. If the honourable senator wants to give some notice of that, I will certainly have the information available at the next Estimates Committee meeting and we will have the matter out, because I look forward to that discussion as much as he does. But I again give him this assurance: there is no manipulation of overseas staff figures to get an outcome. That is not the way to run a global immigration policy. A global immigration policy is run by saying that there will be an even hurdle worldwide. It is selective, of course-selective towards age, skills and concessional points on the basis of kinship. All of those things will apply, but they will apply equally the world over. The fact that the rest of the world is not equal, of course, does not mean that a necessary response is achieved.

I think the honourable senator referred to Italy and to the fact that there has been a reduction in Rome. On my looking at those figures, there are something like 2,800 applications in Rome in 1987-88, of which I think 1,300 were accepted. But at least 1,200 of those were in the refugee special humanitarian region. We had a staff cutback in Rome because of the very severe cutback in demand. From my memory only 600-odd people applied under independent concessional and I think 300 under direct family reunion. Therefore in those sorts of posts we would cutback over a period. We would also have to take into account that in a place like Rome we might not cut back as much as might appear necessary due to demand because of the complexity of a lot of those cases. A lot more work is involved in processing the refugees there. We process the Soviet Jewry mostly out of Rome.

The conditions in countries vary and the needs of the clients vary. It may well be that we can at times cut back in Great Britain because the cases there are simpler to process. I stress again that there can be delays through things like the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act where there is, I admit, up to a 40-week delay. That is something that is being reviewed by the Department of Industrial Relations right now. It is something my Department has obviously continually complained about as it wants it to be resolved. There are quite often infinite patterns of reasons as to why we get these variations. In two or three other capital cities of the world-I do not want to identify them here particularly-processing time is extremely long because of the number of forgeries-forged qualifications, documents, et cetera-that are received. They all have to be sifted through. In other areas the amount of staff we have overseas has absolutely nothing to do with immigration; it is to do with the issuing of visas for visitors. If a certain region of the world surges in terms of visitors, we are more likely to have officers there to deal with those applications and not just immigration matters.

There is nothing simple about this area. If the honourable senator wants a post by post assessment and comparison to test whether the explanation given to him at the Estimates Committee is right, I suggest that we do it in our consideration of the Supplementary Estimates. If he will give us some notice, I will get the officers along. If we have to do a post by post review and give a rationale for why the staffing levels at a particular post are such, I am happy to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that response and I would like to take up the offer to progress on that at the next Supplementary Estimates.

Assuming that is the case, I would like to know how that is happening and what action is being taken in any form to regularise what appears to be a very irregular and illegal situation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short raises three matters. The first one deals with the propriety, or the future, of State government instrumentalities being involved in the business migration program. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short made a throw-away remark that I was critical of an honourable senator for being involved in this area. I think that that was somewhat distorted at the time. Nevertheless, that would have been a perceived conflict of interest and would have been a matter for complaint from other business migration agents. I also put on the record here that I also understand why some honourable senators wish to keep their hand in in their old occupations. This point was clearly illustrated today during the obituary for Senator Little. Only two senators who served with him are still here, yet he left this place only 14 years ago. I do not criticise honourable senators who want to keep their eye in in an alternative occupation. With the hazards of election and preselection haunting us all, that is not unusual.

The third question raised by Senator Short is a particularly sensitive one and he will note that I have made no public comment on it. He may adduce reasons of cowardice or otherwise for not making a public comment, but I will not comment today on the specifics of that particular individual. I can confirm that that individual is in Australia on a temporary entry permit which expires in June 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long has he been here?

—Approximately four years, I believe. I think he has had two temporary entry permits. At the time of the expiration of the permit, or before, that individual has to make a decision whether to apply again for a temporary entry permit or a change of residence status, or leave the country. At that time, I, as the final decision maker, will make any decisions appropriate to the case. I recommend that Senator Short look at a couple of the legal cases involving Immigration Ministers over the last three or four years and at the judgments involved. I think that would quite clearly demonstrate to him why I do not make public statements on these particular cases. I am the final decision maker and any court would expect me not to make a decision on the basis of representations. It would expect me to make a long and considered judgment based on the facts of the case of the time, which I will do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to bring to the attention of the Senate a document which has just been handed to me and which I regard as an indication of scandalous behaviour on the part of the Government.
—Hey?

—No, not Senator Robert Ray in particular, but his colleagues in general. In the course of Estimates Committee A I asked a series of questions relating to the overseas trip by Mr Hayden recently which was cut short. TALK.START.PARA: —We should reopen those Estimates. It is a disgrace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to spend a few minutes talking about alternatives to Australia's current defence strategy of self-reliance within the alliance and the changing nature of warfare. This debate is already under way in Europe and, more recently, in New Zealand, so it is about time that we got such a debate under way in the community in Australia. In fact, my office has been instrumental in working with community groups in promoting a series of Just Defence conferences around Australia since 1986. So far we have organised three-in Canberra, Perth and Adelaide. We were fortunate enough to have the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) at two of them and he promised to attend the third, but the Fiji coup, mark 1, intervened and he was represented by an officer on his personal staff.

SPEECH.PARA: Other speakers have considered defence options ranging from non-offensive defence and territorial defence through to social defence as well as armed neutrality. I advocate a strategy of transarmament, or a step by step movement away from current policy through non-offensive defence and ultimately to social defence. Such a process would extend beyond my lifetime and would have to be accompanied by the strengthening of regional and international conflict resolution mechanisms as well as far more research on peace and conflict research itself.

I do not accept the idea of armed neutrality, which was the subject of debate in this chamber a few days ago. Obviously, I believe in a nuclear free and independent Australia and have stated frequently that I believe that Australia should sever all military ties with the United States of America or any other major power. For more than 40 years the world has been cursed by bloc thinking when both Moscow and Washington propounded the idea `If you are not for us you have to be against us'. If I criticise the United States, I am somehow pro-Soviet. If I criticise the Soviet Union-which I frequently do, despite allegations to the contrary by certain members of this chamber whose politics I sometimes think lie somewhere to the right of Genghis Khan-I am accused of being pro-American or anti-Soviet.

I have long argued that middle ranking powers like Australia should de-align themselves by pulling out of this bloc thinking and following the thinking now growing in Europe of a continent free from the military control of both superpowers, though not within the framework of becoming another superpower themselves. What we should be considering is an appropriate form of defence for Australia as we move towards the twenty-first century. I believe that most Australians still support the ANZUS alliance because, for 200 years, they have been taught that this country, with its 24,000-kilometre coastline, is somehow indefensible and threatened from beyond. Because of this fear, we need a great and powerful protector, or so the considered wisdom has been. Until 1942 Britain provided that protection and, after that, we tumbled into the arms of the United States. The United States was not really interested in an alliance after the war, but it suited it after the Korean war broke out when a series of alliances, including one with Japan and one with the Philippines, were constructed down through the Western Pacific to box in the Soviet Union and Red China, as it was then called.

The other myth that we have to live with is that we are a civilised nation working with other civilised nations which are unfortunately on the other side of the world, while around us there are uncivilised nations and terrorists. We are reminded that wars can break out at any moment and that, if we do not protect ourselves as in the 1930s, we shall be the victims of unprovoked aggression. Great play is made of various Arab-Israeli conflicts and the Falklands-Malvinas conflict in 1982, as recent examples.

The problem with this attitude is that it fails to address the current world situation and the way in which war has changed, and fails to understand the region in which we live. There have been somewhere between 130 and 150 wars in the world since 1945 and about 20 million people have been killed as a consequence. Conservative politicians in this building like to refer to the deterrent value of nuclear weapons, which they are convinced have kept the peace since 1945 or at least prevented a major confrontation. What they ignore is the fact that, because of the existence of nuclear weapons, the nature of warfare has also changed. As Sinathamby Rajaratnam, a former Singapore Foreign Minister, once put it, the third world war is a cumulation of little wars rather than a big one. He said:

Though the form is new, it is basically a war between the great powers and one fought for the realisation of their ambitions and the promotion of their national interests. However, this is not obvious because in this new world war, the great powers are invisible.

While we can welcome the apparent impending close of some of these intractable wars such as the Gulf War and the conflicts in the Western Sahara, Angola and Namibia, a recent article in the Canberra Times on a report by the Commission on Integrated Long-term Strategy in the United States referred to discriminate deterrence, indicating that this continuing confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union is likely to continue and intensify. What is worse is the fact that these wars are going to involve new high tech weapons as well as control of space. At the same time, we know that new weapons are being developed in the Third World including chemical weapons, sometimes called the poor person's nuclear weapon; ballistic missiles; and some of the new smart weapons as well as nuclear weapons, thanks to the spread of so-called peaceful nuclear technology.

What the hardline defence lobbyists in this country fail to realise is that all but one of the wars fought since 1945 have been fought in the Third World. Only 15 per cent of them involved one country invading another. The other 85 per cent have involved the attempted overthrow of colonial governments or have come about for tribal, religious or ethnic reasons, frequently of an internal nature.

Essentially major conflicts can be divided into six groups: colonial wars, wars of liberation, border wars, invasions, separatism and interventionism. The main colonial wars were fought in Africa but wars of national liberation have been and are being fought across three continents with smaller spasmodic conflicts continuing in Europe. Border wars have invariably had their roots in the colonial period, as have separatist struggles. While it is perfectly true that a number of these conflicts have been and are being fought fairly close to Australia-in places like West Papua, East Timor, Indo-China, the Philippines, Burma and Sri Lanka-the fact is that they all come under the categories I have already outlined and none pose a threat to Australia. What we in fact consider our greatest weakness is our greatest strength; that is, our distance from anywhere else. This was the same factor that persuaded the Imperial Japanese Army not to follow up an invasion option it considered early in 1942, and it is still valid today.

The problem we face in Australia in 1988, as we have indeed had to face since the end of the Vietnam War, is how to have a relevant defence force in peacetime. It is the same problem faced by the Europeans. Usually a defence force exists because there is a threat and the armed forces hold war games and exercises relevant to various threat scenarios. In Australia we have $7.6 billion to spend in a year but no threat, or no immediate threat, visible. It has made life very difficult for the Australian Defence Force and I believe it is this paradox that has partly contributed to low morale in the ADF, which was the subject of a recent defence inquiry.

The ADF is caught between the strange glamour that we attach to the military and retired service men and women in Australia and the realities of peacetime. The only way to counter it for the warrior class is either to drum up the glories of the past when we went off to fight other nations' wars, or to invent implausible threats. There are quarrels over what new weapons to buy without asking what they are for. Admirals want aircraft carriers and naval officers want sophisticated new frigates to sail around the Pacific and to join the Americans in exercises designed to fight the enemies of the United States on the other side of the world but they have very little to do with non-existent enemies of Australia in the South Pacific. New Zealand has been asking the same question since faced with a potential bill of $NZ2.1 billion for four new ANZAC frigates which are totally irrelevant to the defence requirements of that country, but very few people in Australia have begun to question the relevance of these very expensive and sophisticated weapons or pieces of equipment-the new frigates, the new submarines and the 75 FA18s-which have made such a hole in our balance of payments.

I believe that the real threats to Australia at the moment come from illegal fishing, dangers of quarantine infection, illegal immigration, and drug smuggling. We are likely to spend over $5 billion on the FA18s but they are of little use in dealing with these current threats to our security, and we cannot afford adequate surveillance of our coastline, which would cost a fraction of the cost of even one FA18. We discontinued production of the Nomad and spent our money on Orions and the new attack aircraft which we had to buy from another country, the United States. Recently I saw that a joint Indonesian-Spanish patrol type aircraft was being advertised in an Australian defence journal, and a defence commentator referring to the advertisement was reflecting how stupid we were to have discontinued production of the Nomad.

If we were constructing aircraft like the Nomad here in Australia along with corvettes, more patrol boats, and the minesweepers we are planning to develop, that would be far more relevant than FA18s, submarines and new frigates, let alone the Opposition's wish list for aircraft carriers and nuclear submarines to be paid for somehow by reducing taxation and government expenditure, as the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) reminded the House of Representatives quite recently. What the warrior class fails to realise is that, if Australia invests in potentially offensive weapons, then so will our neighbours. We have a recent example with India. The Government there, for some reason known only to itself but probably connected with prestige and wanting to be a major power in the region, has decided to acquire several nuclear submarines and a third aircraft carrier. Though we are assured that India is not viewed as a threat, there are Royal Australian Navy men who want Australia to get nuclear submarines and aircraft carriers because India is getting them. This is the action-reaction syndrome that fuels an arms race.

I believe that instead of developing a regional arms race Australia would be far better off developing a non-offensive defence force structure, putting more emphasis on the reserves, training our soldiers in peacekeeping skills for service with the United Nations when called on, and, above all, building up their skills for community service within Australia and the region. I believe that this would do a great deal to improve defence morale and give them something meaningful to do and it would improve their perceived value to the Australian community.

World defence expenditure is continuing to creep upwards but has slowed down with the economic recession. New weapons are being developed by the boffins and are now spreading through the Third World as arms transfers proliferate beyond the control of the old suppliers in the United States and Europe, including the Soviet Union. It is no good bemoaning arms sales and the escalation of the arms race, both internationally and regionally, if we join in. Australia is fortunate to be one of the most secure countries in the world and it is about time that we got over these hang-ups of a past era and put our minds to peace and conflict research rather than preparing for non-existent threats and playing war games in scenarios that are nothing to do with the defence of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate some deficiencies in the social security area which have seen families and pensioners severely disadvantaged. In today's society under this Labor Administration it would appear that the needy and those in poverty have to live within 400 metres of a Department of Social Security office in order to get benefits that I believe they should automatically be entitled to. My State of Tasmania is quite decentralised, with many people living in remote country areas. I have had brought to my attention of late several cases of people having been penalised because they do not live in a situation that is convenient to a Social Security office.

SPEECH.PARA: One particular matter to which I wish to draw the attention of the Senate tonight is that of a self-employed family man who had the misfortune to become ill. This man's annual earnings would make the salaries of people in this chamber look like those of millionaires. He and his wife and children live in a quiet, remote part of the State. His illness progressed to the extent that eventually it led to hospitalisation. During this time neither he nor his wife had been able to lodge an appropriate form for sickness benefit with the Department of Social Security. After all, his wife was looking after a young family and a very sick husband. It was very difficult for her to get to the nearest town to enable a form to be sent to the Department of Social Security. Apart from that, we seem to assume that all sorts of people have a knowledge and understanding of how the bureaucracy works. But not everybody in society, particularly those who live in remote areas, are aware of their entitlements. Even if they are fit, they are perhaps not as speedy as some others. Because the form ended up being lodged outside the 5-week period specified in the claims guidelines-the man had a viral infection; he was on his back; he got worse and went to hospital-the Department refused to backdate this man's claim. This caused untold hardship to the family. The Social Security Act in section 125 (4) provides:
If a claim for sickness benefit is not lodged within the time specified in sub-section (3)-
as mentioned previously, this is five weeks-
the benefit is payable:

(a) if the Secretary is satisfied that the sole or dominant cause of the failure to lodge the claim within that time was the incapacity concerned-from and including such date as the Secretary considers to be reasonable in the circumstances, not being a date earlier than 4 weeks before the day on which the claim is lodged;
(b) in any other case-from and including the day on which the claim is lodged.

Paragraph (a) would appear to give the Secretary the necessary discretion in such cases to approve the backdating of the claim. However, in this case the answer was just plain no. There was just a straightforward no from the Department. I believe a little consideration should and could have been given to this person's unusual circumstances. There is verification of his sickness and his hospitalisation.

Why do departments have such a narrow view? They see only black and white, the easy way out. There is no grey area, despite what the Act says, for people in such necessitous circumstances. Why do departments insist on conforming to the so-called guidelines in cases where departmental officers cannot fit a case into the usual categories. This case was not dealt with just at the counter or at the door; it went to the supervisors and such people. So there is no excuse; the Department had the opportunity to look again at this case.

I appeal to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) as a humanitarian person to do everything in his power to make sure that the Act is applied in a humane way to make sure that what I am sure is the full intent of this section is applied and that at least this person can have the benefit applied for the four weeks. He lived in a remote area; he was hospitalised and he was living substantially below the poverty line. I appeal to the Minister's sense of fairness and judgment and to the Government's sense of fairness. I hope the Minister will do the right thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson has raised a case which I believe merits further deliberation and reconsideration by the relevant officers of the Department of Social Security. In the course of his elaboration of the case he provided some descriptive details while protecting the privacy of his constituent. It would probably be helpful if he were to provide on a confidential basis the name of his constituent so that the matter can be followed up. Any discretion that is vested in the Secretary to the Department by the Social Security Act-obviously I have not been able to verify the provisions quoted-is intended to be used in circumstances which call for a humane rather than an inflexible imposition of the general rule. I will pass the matter on to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), together with the name, if that is provided by the honourable senator.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vallentine raised some matters to do with her vision of how Australia might be better defended with a capacity which she thought was more appropriately tailored to the sort of threat which she perceived Australia to be facing in reality regarding the possibility of armed conflict and combat. I am sure that her oration will be widely circulated in Australia and those who are interested will find in it an alternative point of view to consider.

Senator Alston raised a question relating to a matter which was an addendum to information provided to Senate Estimates Committee A to do with the expenses incurred by the Governor-General designate on a recent overseas trip. I want to say only two things on that because obviously I did not have the opportunity to see the paper which was in the possession of Senator Alston. Firstly, I do not think it is fair to say of the officials concerned in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet that they were deliberately trying to withhold information from this chamber until the last moment. Obviously, the material has been provided at a time which allows it to be brought to the notice of the chamber: indeed, that has been done by Senator Alston. The detail that he may be in possession of might further clarify the situation. For example, it is obvious that because of the reduction in the duration of Mr Hayden's overseas trip the air fare component would look greater on a per diem basis than it would if the original duration of the trip had applied. So there are elements which I think would require further reflection and consideration. I do not accept the various highly emotive descriptions of the expenditure which fell from the lips of the honourable senator from Victoria.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.58 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 May 1988 (Hansard page 3000), Senator Hamer asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the new arrangements for the taxation of superannuation. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the new arrangements for the taxation of superannuation which were announced on 25 May, benefits received from an unfunded superannuation scheme, as commonly found in the Commonwealth public sector, will be liable to tax of 15 per cent (plus the Medicare levy) on rollover into an approved deposit fund. However, on withdrawal from the fund the benefits will obtain relief, compared with the previous arrangements, at least sufficient to offset the tax imposed on rollover. There will, therefore, be no diminution of after-tax benefits as a result of this aspect of the new arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 June 1988 (Hansard page 3341), Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the new superannuation taxation provisions. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The changes to the taxation of superannuation announced in the May Statement included a number of measures which will benefit self-employed persons and `unsupported' employees who make their own provision for superannuation:

The amount of tax deductible contributions such persons are able to make has been doubled, from $1500 to $3000. This effectively doubles the amount that they can save through a superannuation scheme on a tax concessional basis (ie taxed only at the 15 per cent superannuation fund rate).

They will also benefit in full from the generosity of the transitional provisions, which provide phased reductions in the tax rates on the post-1983 assessable component of superannuation benefits of 15 percentage points over the 5 years from 1 July 1988. The generosity of the transitional arrangements arises because the reductions in tax overcompensate for the tax on contributions by applying to the whole of the assessable post-1983 component of an ETP, including that part of a benefit relating to the period between 1 July 1983 and 1 July 1988 when no contributions tax was payable, as well as to the earnings on undeducted contributions.
In addition, the shift from the old $55000 (unindexed) threshold to the new $60000 indexed threshold for end benefits will also assist persons retiring from 1 July 1988 on.

For these reasons, persons retiring in the next 12 to 18 months, irrespective of whether they are employees or self-employed, can generally expect to be marginally better off as a result of the tax changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 August 1988 (Hansard page 260), Senator Parer asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the reduction in beer prices quoted by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech of 23 August 1988. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Parer referred to the reductions in the retail prices of beer recommended by the Australian Hotels Association (AHA) which will flow from the taxation changes announced in the Budget. He noted these would be less than those indicated in the Budget speech.

The estimate of the retail price reductions on beer indicated in the Budget speech, ie about $2.20 for a carton of full strength beer and about $5.50 for a carton of lower alcohol beer, were based on, inter alia, the following assumptions:
(a) that the full strength beer has an alcohol content of 4.9 per cent and the lower alcohol beer has an alcohol content of 2.2 per cent; and
(b) that retailers reduce their prices while maintaining the same percentage profit margin as prior to the tax changes.

The honourable senator raised the question of freight costs. Whether sales tax will be paid on freight costs will depend on marketing arrangements in the industry, which differ in various parts of Australia. This situation is no different to that where other goods are subject to sales tax. Where freight costs are substantial and included in the taxable wholesale sales value, then the net tax payable on the beer will be higher than elsewhere (and the drop in retail price less). However, it was not feasible to present in the Budget speech estimates of the change in retail prices to cover all possible situations.

Nonetheless, the reduction in the retail price of beer should significantly exceed the reduction in the Commonwealth taxation impost. The reduction in Commonwealth taxation should also lead, over time, to a reduction in the amount of State licensing fees paid as these fees are set on a percentage basis. In addition, some reduction in the absolute retail margin can be expected as industry advice suggests that margins tend to be set as a percentage of the wholesale price.

The AHA has recommended retail price reductions of $1.80, and $4.08 on a dozen 750ml bottles of full strength and light beer respectively. There exists scope for further reduction in these prices and the Prices Surveillance Authority has been instructed to monitor beer prices to ensure that consumers receive the full benefits of the Government's reforms in this area. A number of major retailers have already reduced prices by amounts similar to-sometimes larger than-those set out in the Budget and competitive forces are likely to give rise to more widespread reductions.

Senator Button undertook to make inquiries of the Treasurer, who has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:
